revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = AbleGamers Foundation | logo = File:Ablegamers_charity_logo.png | logo_alt = White and orange text logo for The Ablegamers Charity. | type = Public Charity | founded_date = 2004 | leader_title = Founder and Executive Director | leader_name = Mark C. Barlet | founders = Mark Barlet and Stephanie Walker | location = Harpers Ferry, West Virginia | origins = | key_people = Mark Barlet, Steve Spohn, Craig Kaufman | area_served = Internationally | focus = Gamers with Disabilities | method = | revenue = ~$495,000 in 2015 | endowment = | num_volunteers = 300 | num_employees = 2 | num_members = 2000 | owner = | homepage = http://www.ablegamers.org | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''The AbleGamers Foundation''' (also known as '''The AbleGamers Charity''') is an American [[nonprofit organization]] and [[Foundation (non-profit)|foundation]] dedicated to improving accessibility in the video game space, enabling more people with disabilities to be able to play video games.<ref>{{cite web|last=Schuster |first=Shawn |url=http://massively.joystiq.com/2009/04/09/do-developers-consider-disabled-gamers-enough/|publisher=Massively by Joystiq|title=Do Developers Consider Disabled Gamers Enough |date=2009-04-09 |accessdate=1 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Adams |first=Paul |url=https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2011/07/accessible-games/#more-36954|publisher=Wired Magazine|title=Gamers With Disabilities Battle Indifferent Industry |date=2011-07-14 |accessdate=1 October 2016}}</ref> The charity creates resources, assists individuals in getting the peripherals they need, runs scholarships,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/12/01/ablegamers-will-send-3-developers-with-disabilities-to-train-jam-and-gdc-2018/|title=AbleGamers will send 3 developers with disabilities to Train Jam and GDC 2018|last=Minotti|first=Mike|date=1 December 2017|work=VentureBeat|access-date=30 September 2018}}</ref> and works with video game publishers and video game companies to improve accessibility.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.windowscentral.com/ablegamers-xbox-adaptive-controller-interview|title=How AbleGamers aims to bring gaming to those with disabilities|last=Corden|first=Jez|date=5 June 2018|work=Windows Central|access-date=30 September 2018}}</ref>
== History == AbleGamers was founded by Mark Barlet and Stephanie Walker in 2004 after Walker discovered that her [[Multiple sclerosis]] was stopping her being able to properly control a [[computer mouse]] to play video games.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/radio/day6/episode-406-1.4804831/xbox-s-adaptive-controller-aims-to-bring-gaming-to-community-of-disabled-players-1.4804836|title=Xbox's Adaptive Controller aims to bring gaming to community of disabled players|last=|first=|date=8 September 2018|work=CBC|access-date=30 September 2018}}</ref> The charity works with individuals to assess their needs and challenges, determining what equipment they need to help them play video games - including both existing and new, custom-made, hardware. This includes both online consultations and visits to the charity's facilities.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.shacknews.com/article/99906/how-ablegamers-turned-an-old-coast-guard-facility-to-a-hub-for-disabled-gamers|title=How AbleGamers Turned an Old Coast Guard Facility to a Hub for Disabled Gamers|last=Mejia|first=Ozzie|date=9 May 2017|work=Shacknews|access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref> The charity helps up to 300 people every year through direct support, and more through online resources.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/street-fighter-brolylegs-disabled-gamers-hardware-ablegamers-xbox-special-effects-software-players/|title=Playing Street Fighter with your face -- and kicking butt|last=NG|first=Alfred|date=7 April 2017|work=CNET|access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref> While the program was initially opened for applications only at certain times of the year, it began being offered year-round from 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.polygon.com/2013/12/13/5206786/ablegamers-grant-for-gamers-with-disabilities-now-permanently-open|title=AbleGamers grant for gamers with disabilities now permanently open|last=|first=|date=13 December 2013|work=Polygon|access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref>
The charity has opened ''Accessibility Arcade''s in locations such as [[Washington, D.C.|Washington, D.C.'s]] [[Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Library]] and the [[University of Toronto]]'s Semaphore Research Cluster, showcasing accessible hardware and games.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/10/03/ablegamers-foundation-to-open-first-permanent-accessibility-arc/|title=AbleGamers Foundation to open first permanent 'Accessibility Arcade'|last=Mallory|first=Jordan|date=3 October 2012|work=Engadget|access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.polygon.com/2014/4/22/5639808/accessibility-arcade-university-of-toronto-ablegamers|title=Accessibility Arcade for disabled gamers opens April 26 at the University of Toronto|last=Tach|first=Dave|date=22 April 2014|work=Polygon|access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref> In 2013 the charity topped $100,000 [[United States dollar|USD]] in donations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.polygon.com/2014/1/10/5296664/ablegamers-2013-donations-100000|title=AbleGamers donations topped $100,000 in 2013|last=Tach|first=Dave|date=10 January 2014|work=Polygon|access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref>
January 2016 the charity announced that it was extending its mission to include a new program entitled "Expansion Packs". Partnering with sponsors, AbleGamers is building accessible game rooms for activity centers that support people with disabilities, the first being at the Pediatric Specialty Care in Hopewell PA.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pediatricspecialty.com/blog/ablegamers-so-everyone-can-game/|publisher=Pediatric Specialty Care|title=Ablegamers... So Everyone can Game!|date=December 19, 2015}}</ref>
In 2017 AbleGamers started the ''Player Panels'' initiative, whereby gamers with disabilities work with game developers to improve the accessibility of upcoming games, and participate in research studies.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/3204908/gaming/ablegamers-player-panels-could-make-future-games-more-disability-friendly.html|title=AbleGamers' Player Panels could make future games more disability-friendly|last=Chacos|first=Brad|date=29 June 2017|work=PC World|access-date=30 September 2018}}</ref>
The AbleGamers Foundation worked with [[Evil Controllers]] to design accessible peripherals for disabled gamers,<ref>{{cite web|last=Fletcher |first=JC |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2011/06/24/adroit-controller-line-to-make-games-more-accessible/|publisher=Massively by Joystiq|title='Adroit' controller line to make games more accessible|date=2011-06-24 |accessdate=1 October 2016}}</ref> and in 2018 it was announced that the [[Xbox Adaptive Controller]] had been created in partnership with organisations including AbleGamers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/05/17/xbox-adaptive-controller-disabilities-gamepad-microsoft-tour/|title=Xbox Adaptive Controller first look: A new, necessary gamepad|last=Conditt|first=Jessica|date=17 May 2018|work=Engadget|access-date=30 September 2018}}</ref>
=== Center for Inclusive Play === In 2012, The AbleGamers Foundation opened "The AbleGamers Center on Game Accessibility and Inclusive Play" in [[Harpers Ferry]], WV. The center offered a place for people with disabilities to experience new accessible technology as well as a [[Hackerspace|maker space]] for custom controller design and prototyping.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mcvuk.com/development/charity-opens-facility-to-help-disabled-gamers|title=Charity opens facility to help disabled gamers|last=Tipps|first=Seth|date=12 September 2013|work=MCV|access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref>
AbleGamers' facility includes a lifesize Songbird from [[BioShock Infinite]] donated to the charity by [[Irrational Games]] in 2014,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t96tqd_yx5s|title=Songbird has Landed|last=|first=|date=January 2015|website=YouTube|publisher=AbleGamers|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref> in addition to rare items such as original [[Fallout (video game)|Fallout]] concept art and signed games.<ref name=":2" />
AbleGamers expanded to a new facility, The AbleGamers Center for Inclusive Play, in [[Charles Town, West Virginia]] in 2017. The building was previously a [[US Coast guard]] facility,<ref name=":1" /> and includes space to hold consultations, demonstrations, and has a [[3D printing]] studio for manufacturing of specialized equipment. It was funded by a grant from Level Access.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.polygon.com/2017/4/27/15451246/ablegamers-new-facility-west-virginia-disabilities|title=AbleGamers opens new facility to help those with disabilities get back in the game|last=Hall|first=Charlie|date=27 April 2017|work=Polygon|access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref> The new facility is a much larger space with more room for AbleGamers to create and display hardware, now has a dedicated [[Streaming media|streaming]] room, and had many features - such as wide doors - which made it beneficial for supporting disabled guests. AbleGamers would like to have facilities in more locations around the United States in the future.<ref name=":1" />
== Awards == Mark Barlet, president AbleGamers received the 2012 [[American Association of People with Disabilities]] Hearne Leadership Award for his work at AbleGamers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aapd.com/what-powers-us/leadership-awards/|publisher=AAPD|title=Meet the 2012 Hearne Leadership Award Winners|date=March 2012}}</ref>
In 2013, AbleGamers won an MS Society [[Da Vinci Awards|Da Vinci Award]] for their document "Includification: A Practical Guide to Game Accessibility", the first time the award had been given to a document and concept, not a product.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalmssociety.org/chapters/MIG/chapter-news/chapter-news-detail/index.aspx?nid=7648|publisher=National MS Society|date=April 2013|title=da Vinci Award Winners announced at gala April 11, 2013}}</ref>
The foundation distributes its own awards each year to the most accessible games released that year, with winners including [[FIFA 13]] and [[Bayonetta 2]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/fifa-13-named-ablegamers-game-of-the-year/1100-6401970/|title=FIFA 13 named AbleGamers Game of the Year|last=Makuch|first=Eddie|date=2 January 2013|work=IGN|access-date=30 September 2018}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-01-08-ablegamers-names-bayonetta-2-the-most-accessible-mainstream-game-of-2014|title=AbleGamers names Bayonetta 2 the most accessible mainstream game of 2014|last=Matulef|first=Jeffrey|date=8 January 2015|work=Eurogamer|access-date=30 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.polygon.com/2014/1/28/5353992/ablegamers-honors-final-fantasy-14-the-stanley-parable|title=AbleGamers honors Final Fantasy 14, The Stanley Parable|last=Tach|first=Dave|date=28 January 2014|work=Polygon|access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref> The awards are given to games with customisable control schemes and colors, optional or minimal [[Quick time event|quick time events]], and unique features such as Bayonetta 2's one-button combat mode.<ref name=":0" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.ablegamers.com}} *[http://www.includification.com Includification]
{{DEFAULTSORT:AbleGamers Foundation}} [[Category:Video game development]] [[Category:Video game organizations]] [[Category:Game accessibility]] [[Category:Charities based in West Virginia]]

Removing link(s) to "GameZone": Article deleted per [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/GameZone]]. | [[WP:TW|TW]]
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox video game | title = Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem | image = Aliens vs. Predator - Requiem Coverart.png | developer = [[Rebellion Developments]] | publisher = [[Vivendi Games]]{{efn|Released under the [[Sierra Entertainment]] brand name}} | designer = Tim Jones | series = ''[[Alien vs. Predator (franchise)|Alien vs. Predator]]'' | platforms = [[PlayStation Portable]] | released = {{vgrelease|NA|November 13, 2007|EU|November 30, 2007|AUS|December 6, 2007}} | genre = [[Action game|Action]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} '''''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem''''' is an [[action game]] exclusive to the [[PlayStation Portable]], developed by [[Rebellion Developments]] and published by [[Vivendi Games]]. It was released in November 2007 in North America and Europe, and December 2007 in Australia. It is part of the ''[[Alien vs. Predator (franchise)|Alien vs. Predator]]'' franchise, an amalgamation of the ''[[Alien (franchise)|Alien]]'' and ''[[Predator (franchise)|Predator]]'' franchises. ''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem'' is a [[tie-in]] to the [[Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem|film of the same title]], which was released shortly after the game.
The game's plot is loosely based on the film, as players take the role of the film's primary [[Predator (alien)|Predator]]. After the events of the [[Alien vs. Predator (film)|first film]] of the ''Alien vs. Predator'' franchise, the Predator has been charged by his society to hunt down and destroy any trace of Alien activity taking place in a small American town, in order to avoid its detection by humanity.
The game received negative reviews from critics and was described as another entry in a long line of poorly developed movie tie-ins. Reviewers enjoyed the opportunity to play as a Predator, but complained that the game was too easy and not rewarding, particularly the simple [[artificial intelligence]] of enemies. The visuals and audio of the game were also considered of poor quality.
==Gameplay== ''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem'' is a [[Third-person shooter|third-person]] [[action-adventure game]].<ref name="euroreview">{{cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/aliens-vs-predator-requiem-review |title=Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem |last=Gibson |first=Ellie |date=December 10, 2007 |publisher=[[Eurogamer]] |accessdate=March 20, 2009}}</ref> The [[Single-player video game|single-player]] campaign is composed of 15 missions and features the Predator from the film.<ref name="ignreview">{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/11/16/aliens-vs-predator-requiem-review-2 |title=Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem Review |last=Miller |first=Greg |date=November 16, 2007 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> The player has access to Predator weapons as seen in movies and other sources in the franchise, including claws and a shoulder-mounted energy cannon.<ref name="gzreview" /> New weapons from the corresponding film include an energy pistol.<ref name="ignau" />
[[Image:AVPRScreen.jpg|thumb|left|A [[Predator (alien)|Predator]], on the right with claws extended, in battle against several [[Alien (creature in Alien franchise)|Aliens]]]]
The player character also has stealth camouflage and several vision modes that allow him to see in the dark, such as infrared vision.<ref name="palgnreview">{{cite web |url=http://palgn.com.au/sony-psp/10033/aliens-vs-predator-requiem-review/ |title=Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem Review |last=Jastrzab |first=Jeremy |date=January 22, 2008 |publisher=[[PALGN]] |accessdate=August 7, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526132218/http://palgn.com.au/sony-psp/10033/aliens-vs-predator-requiem-review/ |archivedate=May 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> [[Health (gaming)|Health]] is represented by a segmented life bar that regenerates after a successful kill,<ref name="ignreview" /> and an [[Magic point#Synonyms|energy bar]] is also available to provide power for the Predator's weapons.<ref name="ignpreview" /> In addition to destroying Aliens, the Predator must eradicate other traces of their presence, including facehugger husks.<ref name="pocketreview">{{cite web |url=http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/PSP/Aliens+vs+Predator:+Requiem/review.asp?c=5077 |title=Aliens vs Predator: Requiem |last=Hearn |first=Rob |date=December 4, 2007 |publisher=[[Pocket Gamer]] |accessdate=March 20, 2009}}</ref> Aliens, husks, humans, and other potential targets are all represented by icons on a [[HUD (video gaming)|heads-up display]].<ref name="gspotreview" /> The game's camera is manipulated by pressing the [[PlayStation Portable|PlayStation Portable (PSP)]]'s triggers,<ref name="pocketreview" /> and the Predator can "lock on" to opponents using a [[First-person (video games)|first-person view]] to target them with his ranged weapons.<ref name="1upreview">{{cite web |url=http://www.1up.com/reviews/aliens-vs-predator |title=Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem |last=Klepek |first=Patrick |date=January 15, 2008 |publisher=[[1UP.com]] |accessdate=August 7, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160608052902/http://www.1up.com/reviews/aliens-vs-predator |archivedate=June 8, 2016 |df= }}</ref>
''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem'' uses a system of "honor points" to award [[score (gaming)|points]] to players for actions considered honorable for Predators.<ref name="gplanetreview">{{cite web |url=http://www.gameplanet.co.nz/psp/reviews/131417.Aliens-vs-Predator-Requiem/ |title=Aliens vs Predator: Requiem review |last=Ropeti |first=Joe |date=March 5, 2008 |publisher=[[Gameplanet]] |accessdate=March 20, 2009}}</ref> For instance, "tagging" an enemy in first-person mode before killing it adds points,<ref name="gzreview" /> while killing humans reduces points.<ref name="euroreview" /> Honor points are used at the end of each mission to upgrade the Predator's weapons and equipment.<ref name="ignreview" /> In addition to the campaign, a single-player mode called "Skirmish" is available,<ref name="ignreview" /> in which players have five minutes to dispose of as many Aliens as possible in one of the game's [[level (video games)|maps]].<ref name="palgnreview" /> Skirmish can also be played in a [[Cooperative gameplay|cooperative setting]] with one other player using the PSP's "ad-hoc" local wireless mode.<ref name="euroreview" />
==Plot== The protagonist predator has come to Earth in response to a distress signal from a comrade's ship. Upon his arrival in the small [[Colorado]] town of Gunnison,<ref name="avpinterview" /> he learns that Aliens have begun terrorizing the local populace. His mission is to destroy the Aliens and remove any trace of their activity.<ref name="gspotreview">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/aliens-vs-predator-requiem-review/1900-6183818/ |title=Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem Review |last=McInnis |first=Shaun |date=December 7, 2007 |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> After reaching his comrades' ship and erasing its traces from Earth, the Predator's only mission is to exterminate all Aliens in the vicinity.<ref name="palgnreview" />
The Predator travels through rural and urban areas of Gunnison, fighting more Aliens along the way,<ref name="gzreview" /> and occasionally being harassed by human soldiers and civilians.<ref name="pocketreview" /> Finally, the main Alien lair is found in a hospital, where several mines are set by the Predator to bring the Hive down. The game concludes with the final fight against an attacking helicopter and the hospital's destruction. Suddenly, the Alien Queen is seen appearing out of the hospital's rubble, only to be destroyed, along with the entire town, by a nuclear warhead, while the Predator successfully leaves Earth.
==Development== ''[[Alien vs. Predator (franchise)|Alien vs. Predator]]'' began as a franchise in February 1990,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Presents-February-Predator-Heartbreakers-Ceiling/dp/B001B824Q8 |title=Dark Horse Presents #36 Aliens vs Predator (Heartbreakers Ceiling) |publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |accessdate=March 19, 2009}}</ref> when [[Dark Horse Comics]] published a comic book featuring [[Alien (creature in Alien franchise)|Aliens]] from the [[Alien (franchise)|''Alien'' series]] of films in battle against the [[Predator (alien)|title characters]] of ''[[Predator (film)|Predator]]''.<ref name="gspotannounce">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/aliens-fighting-predator-on-psp/1100-6176631/ |title=Aliens fighting Predator on PSP |last=Magrino |first=Tom |date=August 14, 2007 |publisher=GameSpot |accessdate=August 7, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090705015115/http://www.gamespot.com/psp/action/alienpredatorworkingtitle/news.html?sid=6176631&mode=news |archivedate=July 5, 2009 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Both franchises are owned by [[20th Century Fox|Twentieth Century Fox]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/company/co0000756/ |title=Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation (us) |publisher=[[IMDb]] |accessdate=March 19, 2009}}</ref> In November 1990, Fox released ''[[Predator 2]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100403/ |title=Predator 2 (1990) |publisher=IMDb |accessdate=March 19, 2009}}</ref> and one of the final scenes in the film showed an Alien skull inside a trophy case aboard a Predator ship.<ref name="ignpreview">{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/10/15/alienspredator-preview |title=Aliens/Predator Preview |last=Freeman |first=Will |date=October 15, 2007 |publisher=IGN |accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> Fox began licensing merchandise for the new franchise, including comic books and video games.<ref name="gspotannounce" /> In 1993, the first [[List of Alien and Predator games|''Aliens vs. Predator'' video game]] was released; ''Alien vs Predator'' for the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/snes/563511-alien-vs-predator/data |title=Aliens vs. Predator Release Information for Super Nintendo |publisher=[[GameFAQs]] |accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref>
British independent game studio [[Rebellion Developments]] became involved with the franchise in 1994 with the release of ''[[Alien vs Predator (Jaguar game)|Alien vs Predator]]'' for the [[Atari Jaguar]],<ref name="ignpreview" /> described by [[1UP.com]] as "probably the only good Jaguar game ever made".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.1up.com/news/sega-announces-alien-predator-game |title=Sega Announces New Alien vs. Predator Game |last=Bailey |first=Kat |date=February 11, 2009 |publisher=1UP.com |accessdate=August 7, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911094233/http://www.1up.com/news/sega-announces-alien-predator-game |archivedate=September 11, 2016 |df= }}</ref> Rebellion later developed an [[enhanced remake]] of [[Aliens versus Predator (video game)|the game]] for the PC,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/1999/06/12/aliens-vs-predator |title=Aliens vs. Predator |last=Blevins |first=Tal |date=June 11, 1999 |publisher=IGN |accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> which was the first PC game to require a [[video card]] and went on to win a [[BAFTA]] award.<ref name="ignpreview" /><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/analysis-and-features/baftas-interactive-stars-new-rivals-for-gwyneth-743225.html |title=BAFTA's interactive stars: new rivals for Gwyneth? |last=Rodger |first=Jennifer |date=October 24, 1999 |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=March 19, 2009}}</ref> The first feature film in the franchise, [[Alien vs. Predator (film)|''Alien vs. Predator'']], was released in 2004 and did not include a [[tie-in]] video game.<ref name="gspotannounce" /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0370263/ |title=AVP: Alien vs. Predator (2004) |publisher=IMDb |accessdate=March 19, 2009}}</ref> In August 2007, [[Sierra Entertainment]] announced that the company had partnered with Fox to produce a video game corresponding with the sequel film ''[[Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem]]''. Rebellion was identified as the game's developer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamezone.com/news/08_15_07_07_40PM.htm |title=New Aliens/Predator Film To Invade The PSP System |date=August 15, 2007 |publisher=GameZone |accessdate=March 19, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221080031/http://www.gamezone.com/news/08_15_07_07_40PM.htm |archivedate=February 21, 2009 <!--DASHBot--> |deadurl=yes}}</ref> The company, while not strictly [[Handheld game console|handheld-focused]], has a reputation in the industry for developing PSP games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/1585/from_judge_dredd_to_harry_potter_.php?page=2 |title=From Judge Dredd To Harry Potter, Rebellion CEO Jason Kingsley Is Spoiled When It Comes To IP (page 2) |last=Jordan |first=Jon |date=August 8, 2007 |publisher=[[Gamasutra]] |accessdate=March 21, 2009}}</ref>
''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem'' was developed exclusively for the PSP.<ref name="ignau">{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/12/02/aliens-vs-predator-requiem-au-interview |title=Aliens vs Predator: Requiem AU Interview |last=Shea |first=Cam |date=December 2, 2007 |publisher=IGN |accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> Regarding PSP exclusivity, Rebellion lead designer Tim Jones explained "It was basically a matter of logistics. We have a strong heritage with the PSP and have done a number of successful titles such as ''[[Star Wars Battlefront: Renegade Squadron]]''".<ref name="ignpreview" /> Rebellion decided to forego the [[first-person shooter]] format of their earlier ''Alien vs. Predator'' games and instead focused on a third-person perspective,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.1up.com/news/aliens-predator-duking-psp |title=Aliens vs. Predator Duking it Out on PSP |last=Kollar |first=Philip |date=August 15, 2007 |publisher=1UP.com |accessdate=August 7, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160608052915/http://www.1up.com/news/aliens-predator-duking-psp |archivedate=June 8, 2016 |df= }}</ref> with the player taking the role of a lone Predator.<ref name="gzship">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezone.com/news/11_15_07_02_07PM.htm |title=Aliens vs. Predator - Requiem Attacks PSP, Retailers This Holiday |date=November 15, 2007 |publisher=GameZone |accessdate=March 19, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221080832/http://www.gamezone.com/news/11_15_07_02_07PM.htm |archivedate=February 21, 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Unlike previous Rebellion ''Alien vs. Predator'' titles, ''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem'' does not permit players to take the role of Aliens or human [[Marine (military)|Marines]].<ref name="ignau" /> The company used a [[game engine]] of its own creation, and Hal Zabie, associate producer at Sierra Entertainment, said "...the challenge was to deliver high quality graphics while not sacrificing game performance and this is something that Rebellion achieved and will be noticed by players right away."<ref name="avpinterview">{{cite web |url=http://www.planetavp.com/features/interviews/halzabie.shtml |title=Interviews: Hal Zabie |last=Von Kallenback |first=Gareth |date=October 30, 2007 |publisher=Planet AvP |accessdate=August 7, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109001357/http://www.planetavp.com/features/interviews/halzabie.shtml |archivedate=November 9, 2007 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Rebellion was given materials from the film's production, including footage and the full script, in order to recreate the feel of the film and lend authenticity to the game.<ref name="avpinterview" /> The game's plot is loosely based on the film's,<ref name="gzreview">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamezone.com/reviews/aliens_vs_predator_requiem_psp_review |title=Aliens vs. Predator Requiem - PSP - Review |last=Zacarias |first=Eduardo |date=December 9, 2007 |publisher=GameZone |accessdate=August 7, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007003854/http://psp.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r33511.htm |archivedate=October 7, 2008 |deadurl=no}}</ref> with the [[player character]] working to remove traces of Alien and Predator presence in a small American town.<ref name="ignpreview" /> Despite similarities to the movie,<ref name="gspotreview" /> the ending is different and the game does not feature the "predalien",<ref name="ignau" /> a Predator-Alien hybrid introduced in ''[[Alien vs. Predator (film)|Alien vs. Predator]]''.<ref name="palgnreview" /> The directors of the film, the [[Brothers Strause]], are fans of Rebellion's PC ''Aliens vs. Predator'' game and worked with the studio to develop ''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s premise.<ref name="ignau" /><ref name="ignpreview" /> In an interview with [[IGN]], Rebellion's Tim Jones said "Fox is very protective of their franchise and take [sic] great care to make sure it is treated properly. We had to work within strict confines to remain consistent with the movie and everything we did had to be approved by the studio."<ref name="ignau" /> The game's system of honor points was considered crucial by Rebellion, who felt that the Predators, despite being the "bad guys", were characterized by a strict [[Honor code|code of honor]].<ref name="ignpreview" />
{{Quote|"AvP Requiem PSP is set in [[Gunnison, Colorado|Gunnison]], the same small town as seen in the movie. The player assumes the role of the new elite Predator from the film. While many of the locations, weapons, and scenarios are nearly identical to the film, the game designers were given the freedom to make the best game possible, which meant at times rearranging some of the story elements and action set pieces."|Hal Zabie, associate producer at Sierra Entertainment<ref name="avpinterview" />}} Sierra described the game's development as challenging because portable consoles lack the processing power of larger machines.<ref name="avpinterview" /> Rebellion complained about the PSP's lack of a second [[analog stick|analog thumbstick]], stating that it made creating a usable control scheme challenging. They also stated that because the game's protagonist preferred to work alone, ''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem'' would not contain a [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] cooperative mode for the single-player campaign,<ref name="ignau" /> but a "Survival Mode" [[minigame]] would be available where two players could work together to fight Aliens.<ref name="ignpreview" /> The game had a relatively short development cycle,<ref name="avpinterview" /> and was made in less time than the movie.<ref name="ignpreview" />
''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem'' was released on November 13, 2007 in North America, over a month ahead of the film's December 25 opening.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0758730/ |title=AVPR: Aliens vs Predator - Requiem (2007) |publisher=IMDb |accessdate=March 19, 2009}}</ref> It was released on November 30 in Europe and December 6 in Australia.
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 49/100<ref name="mcscore">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/psp/aliens-vs-predator-requiem |title=Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem for PSP Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=August 8, 2016}}</ref> | 1UP = D−<ref name="1upreview" /> | Edge = 5/10<ref>{{cite journal |title=Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem |author=Edge staff |issue=184 |date=January 2008 |page=88 |magazine=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]}}</ref> | EuroG = 4/10<ref name="euroreview" /> | GameRev = C−<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/aliens-vs-predator-requiem |title=Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem Review |last=Parker |first=Tom |date=February 28, 2008 |publisher=[[Game Revolution]] |accessdate=August 8, 2016}}</ref> | GSpot = 5/10<ref name="gspotreview" /> | GameZone = 5/10<ref name="gzreview" /> | IGN = 5.5/10<ref name="ignreview" /> | PALGN = 5/10<ref name="palgnreview" /> | PSM = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref>{{cite journal |title=Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem |date=February 2008 |page=87 |magazine=[[PlayStation: The Official Magazine]]}}</ref> | VG = 6/10<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.videogamer.com/psp/aliens_versus_predator/review.html |title=Aliens Versus Predator: Requiem Review |last=Yin-Poole |first=Wesley |date=December 7, 2007 |publisher=VideoGamer.com |accessdate=August 8, 2016}}</ref> }} ''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem'' received "generally mixed reviews" according to the [[Review aggregator|review aggregation]] website [[Metacritic]].<ref name="mcscore" /> It was considered a poor movie tie-in, an analysis typical of such games.<ref name="palgnreview" /><ref name="gspotreview" /><ref name="1upreview" /><ref name="gplanetreview" /> Reviewers specifically said the game wasn't "bad", just not "good"—[[IGN]], for instance, said, "''AVP'' doesn't suck, but that isn't to say it's good."<ref name="ignreview" /> [[GameSpot]]'s reviewer said, "''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem'' isn't a terrible game; it's just really mediocre."<ref name="gspotreview" /> [[Eurogamer]]'s Ellie Gibson described the game by referencing a colleague's review of ''[[Miami Vice: The Game]]'', a previous Rebellion PSP title, which stated "<nowiki>[</nowiki>''Miami Vice: The Game'' is<nowiki>]</nowiki> one of those games that's not bad, but nor is it ever that good."<ref name="euroreview" /> The week before the movie's release, ''Requiem'' was listed at #5 on [[GameFly|GameFly's]] most-rented PSP titles list.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=16680 |title=GameFly: Holiday Charts Led By ''Assassin's Creed'', ''Mass Effect'' |last=Alexander |first=Leigh |date=December 17, 2007 |publisher=Gamasutra |accessdate=March 21, 2009}}</ref>
One critique was the game's [[difficulty level]], which was described as too easy.<ref name="gzreview" /><ref name="ignreview" /> [[Gameplanet]] called it "shockingly easy" and claimed that upgrades gained through the honor system made the protagonist invincible rather than stronger.<ref name="gplanetreview" /> Eurogamer noted that "furiously button mashing" was generally sufficient to kill most of the game's enemies.<ref name="euroreview" />
{{Quote|"Although it's true that a game's difficulty is hardly the sole indicator of its overall quality, every other part of the game is far too mired in blandness to prevent you from drifting off under the spell of mindlessly simple gameplay."|Shaun McInnis, [[GameSpot]]<ref name="gspotreview" />}}
The [[artificial intelligence]] of the game's enemies, the Aliens, was regarded as lacking,<ref name="euroreview" /><ref name="ignreview" /> and one reviewer noted that their blood was not acidic, a defining characteristic of the creatures from the films.<ref name="gzreview" /> Several reviewers did praise the game's representation of the Predator, however, especially in the early levels.<ref name="palgnreview" /><ref name="gspotreview" /><ref name="gplanetreview" /> {{quote box|width=40%|align=left|quote="Imagine the pitch: 'Ian Predator and Steve Aliens are two neighbours from very different backgrounds. They get on like chalk and cheese, but they learn to tolerate each other's differences through a series of hilarious misunderstandings.<nowiki>'"</nowiki>|source=Ellie Gibson, [[Eurogamer]]<ref name="euroreview" />}} The game's graphics and audio were not well-received,<ref name="euroreview" /><ref name="gzreview" /><ref name="palgnreview" /> with IGN commenting, "There's never a moment that makes you step back and say wow. The textures are muted, the Predator looks alright, but everything is pretty forgettable."<ref name="ignreview" />
Reviewers also took the opportunity to mock the franchise itself,<ref name="pocketreview" /><ref name="1upreview" /> with Eurogamer suggesting that the series be made into a [[sitcom]].<ref name="euroreview" /> Regarding the multiplayer, IGN's Greg Miller said, "This mode was so boring I made up my own story. I was the Mommy Predator and Ryan from the IGN News Team was the Daddy Predator. We were protecting our children -- the cars in the large empty lot we were running around -- from the aliens."<ref name="ignreview" /> [[1UP.com]]'s Patrick Klepek said, "''Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem'' fails to capitalize on its gaming heritage, instead falling prey to the same substandard licensed schlock we're used to from the films."<ref name="1upreview" />
{{clear}}

{{citation style|date=February 2018}}
An '''analytic narrative''' is a [[social science]] research method seeking to combine historical narratives with the rigor of [[rational choice theory]], particularly through the use of [[game theory]].
The goal of analytic narratives is to provide several forms of discipline on the structure of [[Case study|case studies]], such as a game, out of sample tests, and additional predictions that can be tested even if the main assertion about the case cannot.
Analytic narratives (Bates et al. 1998, 2000; Levi 2002, 2004) involve choosing a problem or [[puzzle]], then building a model to explicate the [[logic]] of an explanation for the puzzle or problem, often in the context of a unique case. The method involves: the use of narrative to elucidate the principal players, their preferences, the key decision points and possibilities, and the rules of game in a textured and sequenced account; and the evaluation of the model through comparative statics and the testable implications the model generates. The analytic narrative approach is most attractive to scholars who seek to evaluate the strength of [[parsimonious]] causal mechanisms in the context of a specific and often unique case. The requirement of explicit formal theorizing (or at least theory that could be formalized) compels scholars to make causal statements and to identify a small number of variables as central to understanding the case.
This approach provides two methods for establishing the generalizability of the theory. First, the model in an analytic narrative often affords a range of explanations and predictions. Although the main account of a unique case may not be testable, the model may yield other predictions that can be tested, either in this case or in other cases. Second, as with other methods, out-of-sample tests constitute an important route to [[generalization]]. The presumption today in social science research is that the authors will provide those tests themselves. However, seldom does the level of knowledge for the out of sample case rival the detailed understanding of the original case that puzzled the author. The demonstration of generalizability must rest on a larger community of scholars who take the findings applicable to one place and time to illuminate a very different place and time.
==Further reading==
Bates, Robert H., Avner Greif, Margaret Levi, Jean-Laurent Rosenthal, and Barry R. Weingast. 1998. ''Analytic Narratives''. Princeton: Princeton University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-691-00129-6}} [http://press.princeton.edu/titles/6355.html]
Bates, Robert H., Avner Greif, Margaret Levi, Jean-Laurent Rosenthal, and Barry R. Weingast. 2000. "The Analytic Narrative Project." American Political Science Review, 94: 696-702 [http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:HUL.InstRepos:3710302]
Bates, Robert H., Avner Greif, Margaret Levi, Jean-Laurent Rosenthal, and Barry R. Weingast. 2000. "Reply, ‘Analytic Narratives Revisited’." Social Science History, 24: 685-96.
Elster, Jon. 2000. "Rational Choice History: A Case of Excessive Ambition." American Political Science Review, 94: 685–695.
Levi, Margaret. 2002. "Modeling Complex Historical Processes with Analytic Narratives." In Akteure, Mechanismen, Modelle: Zur Theoriefahigkeit makrosozialer Analyse, ed. R. Mayntz. Frankfurt/Main: Campus Verlag.
Levi, Margaret. 2004. "An Analytic Narrative Approach to Puzzles and Problems." In Problems and Methods in the Study of Politics, ed. I. Shapiro, R. Smith and T. Masoud. New York: Cambridge University Press.
Mongin, Phillippe. 2016. "What Are Analytic Narratives?" HEC Paris Research Paper No. ECO/SCD-2016-1155, June 2016. [https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2796567]
Zagare, Frank. 2011. ''The Games of July. Explaining the Great War.'' Ann Arbor: The University of Michigan Press. {{ISBN|978-0-472-05116-8}} [https://www.press.umich.edu/2098928/games_of_july]
