{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox video game | title = Catherine | image = Catherine Cover Art.png | caption = Uncensored PS3 cover art featuring Catherine | developer = [[Atlus]] | publisher = {{Video game release|JP|Atlus|NA|[[Atlus USA]]|PAL|[[Deep Silver]]}} | director = [[Katsura Hashino]] | producer = Katsura Hashino | designer = Kazuhisa Wada | programmer = Yujiro Kosaka | artist = [[Shigenori Soejima]] | composer = [[Shoji Meguro]] | engine = [[Gamebryo]] | platforms = {{Unbulleted list|[[PlayStation 3]]|[[Xbox 360]]|[[PlayStation 4]]|[[PlayStation Vita]]}} | released = {{Collapsible list|titlestyle=font-weight:normal;font-size:inherit;background:transparent;text-align:left|title=February 17, 2011|'''PlayStation 3''', '''Xbox 360'''{{Video game release|JP|February 17, 2011|NA|July 26, 2011|EU|February 10, 2012|AU|February 23, 2012}}'''PlayStation 4''', '''PS Vita'''{{Video game release|JP|February 14, 2019|WW|2019}}}} | genre = [[Puzzle-platform game|Puzzle-platform]] | modes = [[Single-player]], [[multiplayer]] }} '''''Catherine'''''{{efn|{{nihongo||キャサリン|Kyasarin}}<!-- See [[WP:JFN]] -->}} is a [[puzzle platformer]] video game developed by [[Atlus]]. The game was released by Atlus for the [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]] in Japan and North America in 2011, and in [[PAL region]]s by [[Deep Silver]] the following year. The story follows Vincent Brooks, a man who is beset by supernatural nightmares while torn between his feelings for longtime girlfriend Katherine and the similarly-named beauty Catherine. The gameplay is divided between daytime hours, where Vincent interacts with the characters, and his dreams where he must navigate three-dimensional tower puzzles. The game's ending is affected by moral choices made by Vincent over the course of the story.
''Catherine'' was developed by the same studio behind the ''[[Persona (series)|Persona]]'' series, including producer and director [[Katsura Hashino]], character designer [[Shigenori Soejima]], and music composer [[Shoji Meguro]]. The game began production near the end of ''[[Persona 4]]''{{'s}} development in 2008, with the aim being to create something different from the ''Persona'' series, being aimed more at an adult audience. The English localization was handled by [[Atlus USA]], with the English actors being allowed to adlib some lines.
Reception was generally positive, with critics praising its mature subject matter and gameplay, despite criticism towards its high difficulty. Several journalists also commented on its representation of gender stereotypes. It exceeded Atlus' sales expectations by having sold over half a million units worldwide by the end of 2011. ''Catherine: Full Body'', a remaster featuring an additional love interest named Rin, will be released for the [[PlayStation 4]] and [[PlayStation Vita]] in 2019.
== Gameplay == [[File:Catherine game screenshot.jpg|thumb|left|Gameplay screenshot of the character Vincent navigating through a Nightmare stage]] ''Catherine'' is a [[puzzle platformer]]<ref>{{cite web|title=New Catherine trailer shows gameplay for the first time|author=Ryan Winterhalter|publisher=[[GamesRadar]]|date=January 5, 2010|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/xbox360/catherine/news/new-catherine-trailer-shows-gameplay-for-the-first-time/a-2011010515164065036/g-2010081911452055090|accessdate=March 7, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Atlus Confirms Western Catherine Release|author=Nathan Brown|work=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]|date=March 1, 2011|url=http://www.next-gen.biz/news/atlus-confirms-western-catherine-release|accessdate=April 1, 2011}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=IDV |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[adventure game]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Japanese Video Game Chart: Catherine Sexes Her Way to the Top|publisher=SPOnG|date=February 25, 2011|url=http://spong.com/article/23909/Japanese-Video-Game-Chart-Catherine-Sexes-Her-Way-to-the-Top|accessdate=March 18, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110228224938/http://spong.com/article/23909/Japanese-Video-Game-Chart-Catherine-Sexes-Her-Way-to-the-Top|archivedate=February 28, 2011|df=}}</ref> in which players control Vincent Brooks, who begins having strange nightmares after his girlfriend, Katherine, begins to talk about marriage and commitment. This matter becomes more complicated for him when he meets a girl named Catherine, and begins an affair with her, and the nightmares get more and more intense.<ref name="VGamerNews">{{cite web|url=http://vgamernews.com/articles/3327/catherine-review-learn-your-love-here/|title=Catherine Review: Learn your Love Here!|last=Garner|first=A.|date=Aug 7, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130205195515/http://vgamernews.com/articles/3327/catherine-review-learn-your-love-here/|archivedate=February 5, 2013|df=}}</ref> The main story mode, Golden Playhouse, follows the story between Daytime and Nightmare scenarios. During the daytime, Vincent will converse with his friends as well as try to handle his relationships with Catherine and Katherine. Most of this time takes place in the Stray Sheep bar where Vincent can save and send text messages from his mobile phone, talk to customers, order drinks, play a minigame titled ''Rapunzel'' or listen to a jukebox containing tracks from other Atlus games such as the ''[[Persona (series)|Persona]]'' series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/xbox360/catherine/news/new-mini-games-revealed-for-catherine/a-2011020217623268063/g-2010081911452055090|title=New mini-games revealed for Catherine|first=Ryan|last=Winterhalter|work=[[GamesRadar]]|date=February 2, 2011|accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
The main gameplay takes place in the Nightmare stages. In a nightmarish dreamworld inhabited by other men, who are represented as [[anthropomorphic]] sheep, Vincent must climb up giant staircases that are slowly collapsing underneath him and safely reach the top. To accomplish this, Vincent must push, pull and climb blocks as quickly as possible while avoiding various traps such as spikes and ice. Climbing up steps in quick succession increases a score multiplier, and at the end of the level, players are given an award based on their score. Each stage is split up into numerous areas, culminating in a boss stage in which a nightmarish creature also attempts to kill Vincent. Vincent can move faster depending on how much alcohol he drinks during the day and can earn pillows that allow him to retry levels. There are also several items which can be found or purchased in between stages, such as spare blocks, lightning which removes enemies and energy drinks that allow Vincent to climb more steps at a time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2010/11/30/catherine_drinks/ |title=All About Catherine's Drinks |publisher=Andriasang.com |accessdate=July 22, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707142201/http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2010/11/30/catherine_drinks/ |archivedate=July 7, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Vincent will die if he falls off the bottom of the level, gets caught by a trap or is killed by a boss, with the game ending if Vincent runs out of retry pillows. In between action stages, Vincent can interact with the other sheep, save his game, learn techniques or spend coins on special items. When playing on easy and normal difficulty, players can push the Select/Back button to correct a single block move.<ref>{{cite web |author=Mike Fahey |url=http://kotaku.com/5725398/catherine-gameplay-is-quite-puzzling |title=Catherine Gameplay Is Quite Puzzling |publisher=Kotaku.com |date=January 5, 2011 |accessdate=July 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/692qj7KFC?url=http://kotaku.com/5725398/catherine-gameplay-is-quite-puzzling |archivedate=July 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/f/catherine-video-full-access-preview/a-2011012714652287090|title=Catherine video – Full Access Preview|first=Chris|last=Antista|work=[[GamesRadar]]|date=January 26, 2011|accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
Throughout the game, the choices the player makes during certain sections of the game will affect the development of Vincent's character and the route the story takes place. This is represented by a morality meter, which can change in several ways, such as how Vincent types out a text message to one of the girls, how he answers certain questions and how he converses with non-playable characters. The game features [[Nonlinear gameplay|multiple endings]] based on the route Vincent takes, and has over twenty hours of gameplay.<ref name="Multiple Endings">{{cite web |url=http://scrawlfx.com/2010/08/catherine-is-twenty-hours-long-has-multiple-endings |title=Catherine is twenty-hours long, has multiple endings |first=Sal |last=Romano |date=August 27, 2010 |work= |publisher=Scrawl |accessdate=August 29, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100829024047/http://scrawlfx.com/2010/08/catherine-is-twenty-hours-long-has-multiple-endings |archivedate=August 29, 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref name=GRadar/> In addition to the Golden Playhouse mode, Babel Mode features four large stages playable with up to two players, while Vs Colosseum features two players simultaneously playing a stage in order to reach the top first.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/285619/news/multiplayer-detailed-for-atlus-catherine/|title=Multiplayer detailed for Atlus' 'Catherine'|first=Mike|last=Jackson|work=[[ComputerAndVideoGames.com]]|date=January 27, 2011|accessdate=February 15, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110130061845/http://www.computerandvideogames.com/285619/news/multiplayer-detailed-for-atlus-catherine/|archivedate=January 30, 2011|df=}}</ref>
==Synopsis==
===Setting and characters=== ''Catherine'' takes place in an undefined North American city. The plot is presented as a [[story within a story]] told through ''Golden Playhouse'', a television program described as "like a Saturday morning theatre, with a bit of a ''[[The Twilight Zone (1959 TV series)|Twilight Zone]]'' vibe".<ref name="PSBlogCath"/> A key location in the game is the Stray Sheep Bar, where the main cast meet up on a regular basis and acting as the stage for the game's major events.<ref name="CathBook"/><ref name="CathCharactersStray"/> The story remains the same up to the ending, which varies based upon the choices Vincent has made in both the real world and the Nightmare realm.<ref name="PSBlogCath"/> The plot of ''Catherine'' focuses on three main characters:<ref name="CathGemProfiles"/> * {{nihongo|'''Vincent Brooks'''|ヴィンセント・ブルックス|Vinsento Burukkusu}}, the main protagonist, is a 32-year-old systems engineer [[salaryman]], described as in between independence from his family and getting married. A lifelong bachelor, he lacks any kind of ambition and chooses to avoid the problems of adult life such as his career and possible future marriage, wanting to live a bachelor life as long as possible.<ref name="CathGemProfiles"/><ref name="FamStaffComments"/> Vincent is voiced by [[Koichi Yamadera]] in Japanese,<ref name="FamStaffComments"/> and [[Troy Baker]] in English.<ref name="SilLocalVoiceDirector"/> * {{nihongo|'''Catherine'''|キャサリン|Kyasarin}}, a 22-year-old beauty who seemingly bumps into Vincent in the bar by accident, and ends up spending the night with him. This encounter, and her continued attempts to romance him, become the catalyst for the game's events. Outwardly Catherine is a playful, seductive and free spirited young woman; in reality, she is a [[succubus]] who tempts men for her own ends.<ref name="CathBook"/><ref name="CathGemProfiles"/> Catherine is voiced by [[Miyuki Sawashiro]] in Japanese,<ref name="FamStaffComments"/> and [[Laura Bailey (voice actress)|Laura Bailey]] in English.<ref name="SilLocalVoiceDirector"/> * {{nihongo|'''Katherine McBride'''|キャサリン・マクブライド|Kyasarin Makuburaido}}, a 32-year-old woman who is an old school friend of Vincent's working as an office manager at a clothing manufacturer. Having known each other since high school, Katherine and Vincent meet up again five years prior to the game's events and begin dating. Katherine is trying to push Vincent into marriage, and gets increasingly irritated by his indecisiveness.<ref name="CathGemProfiles"/><ref name="CathKath"/> Katherine is voiced by [[Kotono Mitsuishi]] in Japanese,<ref name="CathKath"/> and [[Michelle Ruff]] in English.<ref name="SilLocalVoiceDirector"/> Other characters featured are {{nihongo|Erica Anderson|エリカ・アンダーソン|Erika Andāson|voiced by [[Junko Minagawa]]/[[Erin Fitzgerald]]<ref name="CathCharactersStray"/><ref name="SilLocalVoiceDirector"/>}} and {{nihongo|Thomas Mutton|トーマス・マトン|Tōmasu Maton|voiced by [[Norio Wakamoto]]/[[Kirk Thornton]]<ref name="CathBtVA"/>}} or "Master", staff at the Stray Sheep Bar that Vincent frequents.<ref name="CathBook"/><ref name="CathCharactersStray"/> Vincent's regular drinking partners at the Stray Sheep Bar are {{nihongo|Orlando Haddick|オーランド・ハディック|Ōrando Hadikku|voiced by [[Hiroaki Hirata]]/[[Liam O'Brien]]<ref name="CathBtVA"/>}}, an old friend and divorcee who holds cynical views on marriage; {{nihongo|Johnny Ariga|ジョニー・アリガ|Jonī Ariga|voiced by [[Takehito Koyasu]]/[[Travis Willingham]]<ref name="CathBtVA"/>}}, a man whose view is that marriage to a destined partner is ideal; and {{nihongo|Toby Nebbins|トビー・ネビンス|Tobī Nebinsu|voiced by [[Kishō Taniyama]]/[[Yuri Lowenthal]]<ref name="CathBtVA"/>}} a young co-worker of Johnny who is eager to marry and has a crush on Erica.<ref name="CathBook"/><ref name="CathCharactersFriends"/> The whole experience is introduced by Trisha, known in Japanese as {{nihongo|Rue Ishida|石田☆ルウ|Ishida Rū|voiced by Junko Minagawa/Erin Fitzgerald<ref name="SilLocalVoiceDirector"/><ref name="CathBtVA"/>}}, the host of ''Golden Playhouse'' who is dubbed the "Midnight Venus".<ref name="CathBook"/><ref name="CathJPPoster"/>
===Plot=== Vincent Brooks is unwilling to commit to marrying longtime girlfriend Katherine. One night at the Stray Sheep Bar, a drunken Vincent meets an enigmatic young woman named Catherine; they have a [[one-night stand]] which turns into an affair. Simultaneously, Vincent begins experiencing surreal nightmares where he and other men must ascend a tower while outrunning terrifying demons; if they fail in the dream, they die in real life.<ref name="CathRef"/> The stress of his [[double life]] and the growing intensity of his nightmares eventually leads Vincent to end the affair with Catherine. In a violent confrontation between Vincent, Catherine, and Katherine, Catherine is seemingly killed; however, the incident is revealed to have occurred in the nightmare, from which Vincent and Katherine escape. The next day, Katherine — who has retained no memory of the nightmare — breaks off their relationship.
Vincent realizes he is seemingly the only person aware of Catherine's existence, and that all of her messages have vanished from his phone. Vincent confronts Mutton, the proprietor of the Stray Sheep who is the only other person he has witnessed Catherine speaking to. He learns that Mutton is [[Dumuzid the Shepherd]], and that Catherine is a [[succubus]] who aided Mutton in his game to kill men who would not commit to marriage and family. Vincent enters the nightmare game one last time, on the condition that he and other men will be freed if he succeeds. Vincent is victorious and defeats Dumuzid, who is revealed to be an associate of [[Astaroth]].<ref name="CathRef"/> From here, there are several possible endings, depending on the player’s actions throughout the game:
*'''Katherine Ending:''' Vincent meets with Katherine, and asks her to take him back. In the “bad” ending, she refuses. In the “good” ending, she forgives him after Mutton and Vincent’s friends reveal his ordeal. In the “true” ending, they are married. *'''Catherine Ending:''' Vincent summons Catherine, and asks her to be his wife. In the “bad” ending, she refuses. In the “good” ending, Catherine accepts; they live together in [[Hell]] despite the objections of [[Nergal]], the King of Hell and Catherine’s father. In the “true” ending, Vincent overthrows Nergal, becoming the King of Hell with Catherine as his queen. *'''Freedom Ending:''' Vincent realizes he does not desire marriage. Having won against Mutton, he demands payment from him, which he immediately uses to bet on a wrestling match. In the “good” ending, he loses the bet. In the “true” ending, he wins and uses the money to fulfill his dream of [[Space tourism|visiting outer space]].
In all of the game’s endings, Trisha states in a closing narration that the purpose of Vincent's story, and the player's actions in directing his story, was to determine whether the player desired a life of comfort or a life of excitement. She explains that tower was a [[Hero's journey|metaphor for the journey to adulthood]], and that "there is no right way to climb the tower."<ref name="CathBook"/> In a secret ending unlocked when the player clears the game’s challenge stages, Trisha [[Breaking the fourth wall|speaks directly to the player]] and reveals that she is [[Ishtar]], with Astaroth having been one of her avatars. Having grown tired of Dumuzid’s infidelity, the events of ''Catherine'' were a test to find someone worthy of her love. She offers to make the player into a deity so that they can become her consort.<ref name="CathBook"/>
==Development== ''Catherine'' was developed by the "2nd Creative Production Department", a team within [[Atlus]] who had previously handled development for the ''[[Persona (series)|Persona]]'' series, a subseries within the ''[[Megami Tensei]]'' franchise.<ref name="CatherineDev"/><ref name="4Gcatherine"/> Planning for ''Catherine'' began while the development team were performing final polishing work for ''[[Persona 4]]'' prior to the latter's 2008 release.<ref name="4Gcatherine"/><ref name="FamCathOrigins"/> ''Catherine'' was the very first title developed by Atlus for [[High-definition video|high-definition]] (HD) [[video game console]]s, specifically the [[PlayStation 3]] (PS3) and [[Xbox 360]] (360).<ref name="FamStaffComments"/><ref name="FamCathOrigins"/> It used the third-party [[Gamebryo]] [[game engine]].<ref name="CathBryon"/> While they had the option of developing the title for [[Handheld game console|handheld consoles]] or [[mobile device]]s, Hashino felt that the game would lose its charm on less powerful hardware. Using HD consoles they were able to fully portray the world of ''Catherine''. Despite the shift onto HD consoles making their vision easier to realize, debugging for multiple consoles caused problems that pushed back the planned development schedule.<ref name="FamCathOrigins"/> In a 2012 statement, an Atlus staff member said that ''Catherine'' was a "difficult" game for the company to make.<ref name="CathNaoki"/> The game would later be called a "test" for the development of the [[Persona 5|next ''Persona'' title]].<ref name="4Gcatherine"/>
The aim with ''Catherine'' was to create a game that was not within the role-playing genre as with the majority of Atlus' titles, in addition to making something that was aimed at adults. The main aim was to create something new as a change prior to developing a new role-playing game.<ref name="FamStaffComments"/> The three key staff members were all veterans of the ''Persona'' series: director and producer Katsura Hashino had helmed both ''[[Persona 3]]'' and ''Persona 4''; art director and character designer [[Shigenori Soejima]] had designed characters for both ''Persona 3'' and ''Persona 4''; and composer [[Shoji Meguro]] had created music for multiple ''Megami Tensei'' titles, including the ''Persona'' series. The chief designer was Kazuhisa Wada, while the chief programmer was Yujiro Kosaka.<ref name="FamStaffComments"/><ref name="4Gcatherine"/><ref name="CathStaffANN"/> The initial story was written by Hashino, who originally worked alone on the scenario before other writers were brought on to help.<ref name="CathInfoDeng"/> Hashino felt that ''Catherine'' was an ambitious title due to its themes and subject matter, saying that no-one but Atlus would have supported the project. The main theme is love between men and women, although in its infancy the project was themed around conflict. In order to make the love triangle between Vincent, Catherine and Katherine sound realistic, he asked other members of Atlus staff for their experiences. One story, where a woman detailed killing people in her dreams, was almost directly referenced within the game.<ref name="CathInfoDeng"/>
Soejima, who had mainly worked on the ''Persona'' series up to this point, was most focused on making the characters' expressions seem realistic within the context of the story.<ref name="FamStaffComments"/> All the characters were designed around being realistic, with their proportions being more akin to real people rather than stylized figures.<ref name="CathSoejima1"/><ref name="P5magazine"/> According to him, he was influenced by the game's themes of instinctual desire intruding into everyday life, the desire for sleep, and the concept of greed. Vincent exemplified these themes.<ref name="CathSoejima2"/> Vincent's character was based on and named after [[Vincent Gallo]], specifically his appearance in the 1998 film ''[[Buffalo '66]]''. The younger "Catherine" was designed to be beautiful and youthful when compared to "Katherine", who had an adult charm.<ref name="CathInfoDeng"/> The pink coloring of the game's [[user interface]] was intended to evoke its sensual and "kitschy" atmosphere.<ref name="CathUI"/> The cutscenes were created by anime production studio [[Studio 4°C]].<ref name="CathStaffANN"/> While the ''Persona'' games up to that point boasted around half an hour of cutscenes, the number in ''Catherine'' came to considerably more. Studio 4 °C spent around a year working on the anime cutscenes.<ref name="CathInfoDeng"/>
Meguro began working on the first demo tracks for the game in August 2009. Meguro worked as the main composer, leading a team composed of himself, Kenichi Tsuchiya, Atsushi Kitajoh, and Toshiki Konishi. Kitajoh was the general coordinator and managed sound effects for the action scenes.<ref name="MeguroCathLiners"/> Meguro did not have much freedom with the project, as Hashino was specific about that he wanted the music to be like. The key words he was given were "classic", "adult oriented" and "erotic".<ref name="FamStaffComments"/> Meguro and his team used multiple genres for the music in ''Catherine'', switching genre depending on the flow of gameplay; action segments used remixes of Classical music, quiet moments used jazz, and the anime cutscenes used strings.<ref name="CathShoji2"/> Meguro found creating music for the anime cutscenes difficult when compared to earlier projects within the company, as he had to match his music's beat to work by an external company. To help cope Meguro received aid from Tsuchiya, a long-time collaborator on previous cutscene-based pieces.<ref name="CathShoji1"/> Meguro was highly impressed by both the sound quality compared to his previous work with the company, and the amount of control were was adjusting the relative volume of music and sound effects.<ref name="FamStaffComments"/><ref name="CathShoji1"/>
==Release== [[File:Catherine XBox 360 Japan.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Uncensored Xbox 360 cover art featuring Katherine. The differing covers of the 360 and PS3 versions were intended to catch consumer eyes in stores, and exemplify the contrasting appeal of the two heroines.<ref name="CathPackagingJP"/>]] ''Catherine'' was first announced in August 2010, along with its prospective platforms.<ref name="CathAnnounced"/> Upon its announcement, ''Catherine'' proved unexpectedly popular, garnering as much public attention and fan expectation as recent releases in the ''Persona'' series.<ref name="CathInfoDeng"/> Due to the game's content, Atlus found it difficult to gain their wished-for rating from Japan's [[Computer Entertainment Rating Organization|CERO]] ratings board.<ref name="FamCathOrigins"/> Beginning from October 2010, Atlus and its then-parent Index Media began a "aggressive" advertising campaign to promote the title in Japan.<ref name="SilHashino"/> ''Catherine'' released on February 17, 2011.<ref name="CathDateJP"/> A PS3 demo for the game was released in January, but in early February Atlus pulled the demo, stating that it had achieved the maximum number of planned downloads.<ref name="CathJPDemo"/> Following player complaints about the game's difficulty, Atlus created a patch which added a lower difficulty. The patches for both the PS3 and 360 versions released in March.<ref name="CathJPpatchPS3"/><ref name="CathJPpatch360"/> The PS3 version was released in mainland Asia on July 26, 2011, distributed by Softsource. The 360 version was not released in the region due to unspecified coding issues.<ref name="CathAsiaRelease"/>
Different cover artwork was created by Soejima for the 360 and PS3 versions—the PS3 cover showed Catherine showing off her cleavage, while the 360 cover had Katherine lying on her front showing her behind. Soejima was originally told by Hashino to create covers that would catch people's eyes in stores; the different cover arts for different versions was chosen as they felt it would be interesting. The two characters were originally going to be in identical, near-naked poses. This was changed due to the character's different charms, which it was felt would be lost if they were posed in such a way. Soejima went through multiple cover designs, with one being the two characters holding different cutlery utensils. Hashino had little involvement beyond his initial instruction, but did ask that more of Katherine's back be shown in the image. The covers exemplified each character's contrasting appeal: Catherine's cleavage showed off her youthful beauty, while displaying Katherine's behind was meant to evoke her more motherly charms.<ref name="CathPackagingJP"/> This artwork was used for retail posters, but Atlus also created alternate artwork for stores that wanted something less risque.<ref name="CathJPPoster"/>
''Catherine'' was initially not planned for a Western release.<ref name="CathJPexclusive"/> After an initial leak through listings on [[EB Games]] and [[Gamestop]], Atlus USA confirmed that ''Catherine'' would be released in North America.<ref name="SilCathUSannounced"/> Atlus USA initially had difficulty persuading mainstream stores like [[Target Corporation|Target]] and [[Walmart]] to take ''Catherine'' due to its suggestive cover art and marketing calling it an "adult" title, which was mostly associated with erotic games not sold in such stores. To convince them that the game was suitable for mainstream stores, Atlus USA put together a film reel of clips from unspecified [[AAA (video game industry)|triple-A]] games those stores did sell that featured more explicit content than ''Catherine''. When they met the retailer representatives, they showcased the film and pointed out that ''Catherine'' had none of that content, before showing off the most explicit scenes in the game to prove their point. The retailers were convinced and allowed ''Catherine'' to be sold in mainstream stores, and were also convinced into looking through their stocks as concerns were raised due to the film showcasing other games' erotic content.<ref name="CathWestStores"/> As with the Japanese version, Atlus used alternate covers for the 360 and PS3 versions. In addition, they created alternate versions of those covers that toned down the suggestive elements for stores catering to more sensitive consumers.<ref name="SilCathCoversWest"/> ''Catherine'' released in North America on July 26, 2011.<ref name="CathUSDate"/> In addition to the standard edition, a special limited "Love is Dead" edition was created for both PS3 and 360.<ref name="CathNAcollectors"/>
Though initial statements from Atlus said that ''Catherine'' would not be released in Europe,<ref name="CathEUdetails"/> its release in the region was leaked through a rating for the 360 version in Germany.<ref name="CathEUleak"/> Its official release was confirmed in a press release from Atlus shortly after the leak. The title was published by [[Deep Silver]] across all PAL territories, and featured written language support for English, Spanish, German, French, and Italian. Deep Silver was chosen as the publisher as they shared Atlus' enthusiasm about the game.<ref name="CathEUannounced"/> ''Catherine'' released in Europe on February 10, 2012.<ref name="CathEUdate"/> As with North America, the PS3 and 360 versions had a limited special edition. Called the "Stray Sheep Edition" after a central location in the game, it had differing content to the North American edition.<ref name="CathEUcollectors"/> In Australia, the title was distributed by QV Software.<ref name="CathAUqv"/> The PS3 version released on February 16,<ref name="QVcathPS3"/> while the 360 version released on February 23.<ref name="QVcath360"/>
===Localization=== {{multiple image | align = right | footer = [[Troy Baker]] (left) and [[Laura Bailey (voice actress)|Laura Bailey]] (right) were the respective English voices for Vincent and Catherine. Describing the localization as a positive experience, they were free to adlib with their respective characters.<ref name="CathBakerInterview"/><ref name="CathBaileyInterview"/> | image1 = Troy baker taiyoucon 2011 cropped.jpg | width1 = 130 | alt1 = A 34-year-old man with spiky blonde hair, smiling at something to the left of the camera. | image2 = Laura Bailey SDCC 2016.jpg | width2 = 160 | alt2 = A 34-year-old woman with long, brown hair, smiling at someone to the right side the camera. }} The game was localized for the West by [[Atlus USA]], who had previously handled many of the company's earlier titles.<ref name="SilLocalVoiceDirector"/> Main localization staff included editors Mike Meeker and Clayton S. Chan; and [[quality assurance]] staff Scott Williams, Jonathon Reinhold, Kourtnie McKenzie, Allie Doyon and Charles Chaikaew.<ref name="KotoCathLocalInterview"/> Compared to previous Atlus titles, which had focused on Japanese culture, Atlus USA had comparatively little work adjusting things for a Western audience as the game was set within a North American city environment. Their main issue was with the dialogue, which was meant to be naturalistic despite some tongue in cheek dialogue, alongside jokes and references that needed adjusting so they would make sense to a Western audience. According to the localizers, the problem "[wasn't] translating the definition, it's translating the intent".<ref name="PSBlogCath"/> A major issue the team faced was with the quotes used in loading screens. While they were apparently all famous quotes, they had been taken from a Japanese book of quotes without any authors being mentioned, in addition to their translation into Japanese sometimes being poor. In the event, Atlus USA went with new quotes to put in their place rather than trying to identify and translate the existing quotes. The quotes used were from multiple sources, including [[Douglas Adams]], [[George Carlin]] and [[Rodney Dangerfield]]. According to Chan, the main advantage of ''Catherine'' compared to other projects was that the situations and characters were ones he and other team members could understand rather than typical fantasy scenarios.<ref name="KotoCathLocalInterview"/>
Valerie Arem of PCB Productions was the voice director for dubbing.<ref name="SilLocalVoiceDirector"/> Rather than recording as a team, each actor recorded their lines separately.<ref name="CathRuffInterview"/> Baker, Bailey and Willingham, the respective voices of Vincent, Catherine and Johnny, described the voice recording period as a positive experience, reinforced by the fact that they were all old friends. Baker noted that it was a relative rarity for this to be the case in general voice acting.<ref name="CathBakerInterview"/><ref name="CathBaileyInterview"/> Ruff, the voice of Katherine, was helped in her performance by both Arem and Atlus staff.<ref name="CathRuffInterview"/> In contrast to the majority of Japanese game localizations, the lip movements for some cutscenes were adjusted so they would sync with the English voices. This was done to give the acting and performances a more natural feel. This meant that the voice actors had more freedom to adlib parts of their performance: a cited example was the fight between Katherine and Catherine, where the two actresses adlibed the majority of the characters' argument. The aim for realism also meant that the performances were more restrained than those given for Japanese anime, which leaned towards stylized performances.<ref name="SilLocalVoiceDirector"/> For real-time cutscenes, lines had to be matched with gestures and line lengths to within 0.2 seconds; the Atlus staff needed to go through the Japanese script and create a dedicated column for speaking times, then they acted out the lines themselves so they had a reference for the voice actors, and finally they would allow an actor to alter things a little to suit their performance and document those changes so the subtitles matched.<ref name="KotoCathLocalInterview"/>
Baker, Bailey and Ruff had all previously worked with Atlus on the ''Persona'' series: Ruff voiced Yukari Takeba in ''Persona 3'' while Baker and Bailey respectively voiced [[Kanji Tatsumi]] and Rise Kujikawa from ''Persona 4''.<ref name="CathBakerInterview"/><ref name="CathRuffInterview"/><ref name="BaileyRise"/> In an interview, Baker described the Atlus USA staff as giving him and the other English actors a great deal of freedom when it came to delivering lines and portraying their characters. He noted that the themes in ''Catherine'' were far more controversial compared to earlier titles he and Atlus had worked on, and that it was a unique voice acting opportunity.<ref name="CathBakerInterview"/> Bailey was working on another Atlus project when she was offered the opportunity to voice Catherine. Having already heard of the project in the press, Bailey accepted the offer; during her time recording lines, she found the experience strange as she considered Baker to be a brotherly figure, starkly contrasting the relationship between Vincent and Catherine.<ref name="CathBaileyInterview"/> Ruff was offered the role of Katherine based on her acting abilities and her previous work with Atlus. She saw some footage of Katherine to get a feeling for her relationship with Vincent, but did not try to sync her performance with the Japanese. This was partly because of the planned English sync adjustments, and partly because she heard Japanese voice recording and cutscene finalization was still in progress.<ref name="CathRuffInterview"/> This was confirmed by Arem in a separate interview. Arem described each main actor's strengths during recording: Baker had good timing when it came to delivering his lines, Bailey required few retakes, while Ruff was able to realistically convey a variety of emotions. She also noted the work done by Fitzgerald, the voice actress for both Trisha and Erica; Fitzgerald had difficulty with the timing for Trisha's lines, but managed to "pull it off".<ref name="SilLocalVoiceDirector"/> The amount of voice acting involved was so large that the actors felt they could not finish it.<ref name="CathBakerInterview"/> Looking back on the production, Arem said she would not recast any of the characters.<ref name="SilLocalVoiceDirector"/>
==Professional competition== ''Catherine'' is occasionally played competitively in [[eSport]] tournaments. The game's professional scene began when [[Fighting game community|FGC]] member David "Dacidbro" Broweleit desired to learn the insides of the game's engine.<ref name="PasteComp">{{cite web|last1=Walker|first1=Ian|title=An Inside Look At The Competitive Catherine Gaming Scene|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2016/11/an-inside-look-at-the-competitive-catherine-gaming.html|website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|accessdate=January 7, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170108192009/https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2016/11/an-inside-look-at-the-competitive-catherine-gaming.html|archivedate=January 8, 2017|df=}}</ref> The first notable tournament was an event called Super NorCal Install, which took place in 2012. The tournament would become the basis for the game's competitive scene.<ref name="RBComp">{{cite web|last1=Kemps|first1=Heidi|title=The Kings of Catherine|url=http://www.redbull.com/us/en/esports/stories/1331831819270/the-kings-of-competitive-catherine|website=[[Red Bull]]|accessdate=January 7, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170108190659/http://www.redbull.com/us/en/esports/stories/1331831819270/the-kings-of-competitive-catherine|archivedate=January 8, 2017|df=}}</ref> Publisher [[Atlus]] would later officially sponsor the game as a side event at [[Evo 2015]], while streaming it on their [[Twitch.tv]] account.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McWhertor|first1=Michael|title=Watch Evo 2015, the year's biggest fighting game tournament, all weekend|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/7/17/8985053/evo-2015-fighting-game-schedule-livestream|website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|accessdate=January 7, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170111092907/http://www.polygon.com/2015/7/17/8985053/evo-2015-fighting-game-schedule-livestream|archivedate=January 11, 2017|df=}}</ref> The attention surrounding the event would later carry on into [[Evo 2016]], [[Community Effort Orlando|CEOtaku 2016]],<ref name="PasteComp"/> [[Genesis (tournament)|Genesis 4]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Martin|first1=Michael|title=Genesis 4 expands beyond Smash lineup, adds Street Fighter V|url=https://ca.news.yahoo.com/genesis-4-expands-beyond-smash-lineup-adds-street-fighter-v-183910999.html|website=Yahoo News|accessdate=January 8, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109023236/https://ca.news.yahoo.com/genesis-4-expands-beyond-smash-lineup-adds-street-fighter-v-183910999.html|archivedate=January 9, 2017|df=}}</ref> as well as an event in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] called ''The King of Catherine'', which had awarded a $5,000 prize pool to winners.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gach|first1=Ethan|title=Watch The King Of Catherine Tournament Going On Right Now|url=http://kotaku.com/watch-the-king-of-catherine-tournament-going-on-right-n-1788907325|website=[[Kotaku]]|accessdate=January 7, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170108190717/http://kotaku.com/watch-the-king-of-catherine-tournament-going-on-right-n-1788907325|archivedate=January 8, 2017|df=}}</ref>

|award7Pub = GameZone }}
''Catherine'' received mostly positive reviews from critics. It holds average aggregate scores of 82 and 79 out of 100 for the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 versions, respectively, on [[Metacritic]].<ref name="mc_360"/><ref name="mc_ps3"/> In an import review, [[GamesRadar]] gave the game a 5/10, praising the story but criticizing the game's difficulty due to random enemy AI,<ref name=GRadar>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/f/catherine-import-review/a-2011030816833522052 |title=Catherine import review |publisher=GamesRadar |date=March 8, 2011 |accessdate=July 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69nRm3PcE?url=http://www.gamesradar.com/catherine-import-review/ |archivedate=August 9, 2012 |df= }}</ref> though they later gave the English release 8/10, citing crucial changes had removed most of the game's annoyances.<ref name="gradar_english">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/ps3/catherine/review/catherine-review/a-20110725162620661034/g-20100819114534837010 |title=Catherine Review |publisher=GamesRadar |date=July 25, 2011 |accessdate=July 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69nRke3Xw?url=http://www.gamesradar.com/catherine-review/ |archivedate=August 9, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Some Japanese gamers have complained that the game is too difficult, even on the easy setting. Atlus has since released a patch that includes a Super Easy mode, which is included in the English version.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2011/03/09/catherine_super_easy_patch/ |title=Catherine Super Easy Patch Now Available For PlayStation 3 |publisher=Andriasang.com |accessdate=July 22, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69nSGPZeO?url=http://andriasang.com/comuaj/catherine_super_easy_patch/ |archivedate=August 9, 2012 |df= }}</ref> IGN gave the North American version of ''Catherine'' an overall score of 9.0.<ref name="ign_catherine">{{cite web |author=Colin Moriarty |url=http://ps3.ign.com/articles/118/1181622p2.html |title=Catherine Review – PlayStation 3 Review at IGN |publisher=Ps3.ign.com |date=February 17, 2011 |accessdate=July 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717121422/http://ps3.ign.com/articles/118/1181622p2.html |archivedate=July 17, 2011 |df= }}</ref> [[Computer and Video Games]] gave the game an 8.0.<ref name="GAVG">{{cite web |url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/299467/reviews/catherine-review/ |title=Review: Catherine Review |publisher=ComputerAndVideoGames.com |accessdate=July 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69nRw46Fa?url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/299467/reviews/catherine-review/ |archivedate=August 9, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Tom Bissell of Grantland.com, the sports and pop culture website owned by ESPN and run by [[Bill Simmons]], was pleasantly surprised by the game and gave it a very positive review, which included a listing of its eerie qualities.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bissell|first=Tom|title=Sexyweird: On Catherine|url=http://www.grantland.com/story/_/id/7088651/catherine|publisher=Grantland.com|accessdate=October 13, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015125916/http://www.grantland.com/story/_/id/7088651/catherine|archivedate=October 15, 2011|df=}}</ref>
===Sales=== The PlayStation 3 version topped the Japanese charts in its opening week with over 140,000 copies sold while the Xbox 360 version came in 7th with over 21,000, and was able to outsell ''[[Marvel vs. Capcom 3: Fate of Two Worlds]]'', which was released on the same day, by a margin of two-to-one.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/290521/news/catherine-tops-marvel-vs-capcom-in-japanese-chart-battle/|title=Catherine tops Marvel Vs Capcom in Japanese chart battle|first=Tom|last=Ivan|work=[[ComputerAndVideoGames.com]]|date=February 23, 2011|accessdate=March 10, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69nSHChfP?url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/290521/catherine-tops-marvel-vs-capcom-in-japanese-chart-battle/|archivedate=August 9, 2012|df=}}</ref> The game has also been commercially successful in America, selling 78,000 copies across both systems to consumers in its first six days, making it Atlus' biggest launch yet for a game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2011/08/11/npd-catherine-sold-78k-copies-in-july/|title=NPD: Catherine sold 78K copies in July|first=Ludwig|last=Kietzmann|publisher=Joystiq|date=August 11, 2011|accessdate=August 12, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69nSIVDgg?url=http://www.joystiq.com/2011/08/11/npd-catherine-sold-78k-copies-in-july/|archivedate=August 9, 2012|df=}}</ref> The game has sold around 500,000 copies by the end of 2011, being a huge success for the company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/6341146/catherine-tops-500000-units-sold|title=Catherine tops 500,000 units sold|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=October 19, 2011|accessdate=October 19, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111023002127/http://www.gamespot.com/news/6341146/catherine-tops-500000-units-sold|archivedate=October 23, 2011|df=}}</ref> The game sold 260,000 copies in Japan and 230,000 in North America by the end of 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andriasang.com/comyog/|title=More on Catherine's Sales and Persona in 2012 From the Atlus Earnings ==Legacy== Since its release, ''Catherine'' has appeared on several lists of the top games of the [[History of video game consoles (seventh generation)|seventh generation era of video game consoles]]. In August 2012, IGN placed the game at number eighteen on its list of "The Top 25 PlayStation 3 Games", with editor Colin Moriarty praising it as "authentically unique" after calling it an example of something "that's so radically unlike anything else that came before it that it's hard to ignore."<ref>{{cite web |first1=Greg |last1=Miller |first2=Colin |last2=Moriarty |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/08/20/the-top-25-playstation-3-games-2?page=2 |title=The Top 25 PlayStation 3 Games |page=2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=August 20, 2012 |accessdate=June 26, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130825025613/http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/08/20/the-top-25-playstation-3-games-2?page=2 |archivedate=August 25, 2013 |df= }}</ref> The next year in September 2013, ''Catherine'' ranked twenty-fourth on IGN's updated "Top 25 PlayStation 3 Games" list, with Moriarty stating that "the puzzles are both challenging and fun, but what makes ''Catherine'' truly stand apart is its daring subject matter and its unapologetic nudging to make us confront some incredibly uncomfortable – but tempting – situations."<ref>{{cite web |first1=Colin |last1=Moriarty |first2=Andrew |last2=Goldfarb |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/09/03/igns-top-25-playstation-3-games |title=IGN's Top 25 PlayStation 3 Games |page=1 |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=September 3, 2013 |accessdate=June 26, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414083554/http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/09/03/igns-top-25-playstation-3-games |archivedate=April 14, 2014 |df= }}</ref> In November 2013, ''[[Hardcore Gamer]]'' ranked the game seventy-ninth on its "Top 100 Games of the Generation" list,<ref>{{cite web |author=HG Staff |url=http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2013/11/05/games-of-the-generation-80-61/60853/ |title=Top 100 Games of the Generation 80-61 |work=[[Hardcore Gamer]] |date=November 5, 2013 |accessdate=June 26, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714123705/http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2013/11/05/games-of-the-generation-80-61/60853/ |archivedate=July 14, 2014 |df= }}</ref> while ''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]'' placed it at number eight on its list of "The 25 Most Underrated Games Of the Last Console Generation".<ref>{{cite web |first=Steve |last=Haske |url=http://www.complex.com/video-games/2013/11/most-underrated-games-last-gen/cat#gallery |title=08. Catherine — The 25 Most Underrated Games Of the Last Console Generation |work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]] |date=November 14, 2013 |accessdate=June 26, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131117143556/http://www.complex.com/video-games/2013/11/most-underrated-games-last-gen/cat#gallery |archivedate=November 17, 2013 |df= }}</ref> That same month, [[PSU.com|PlayStation Universe]] ranked ''Catherine'' number seventy-three on its list of "The Best 100 Games Of the PS3 Generation", stating that its "core puzzle-platforming offers nerve-wracking excitement" and praised its "engaging, authentic story."<ref>{{cite web |author=PSU Staff |url=http://www.psu.com/a021807/The-Best-100-Games-Of-the-PS3-Generation?page=6 |title=The Best 100 Games Of the PS3 Generation |page=6 |publisher=[[PSU.com]] |date=November 28, 2013 |accessdate=June 26, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140206145918/http://www.psu.com/a021807/The-Best-100-Games-Of-the-PS3-Generation?page=6 |archivedate=February 6, 2014 |df= }}</ref> In January 2014, ''Catherine'' was included on [[Game Revolution]]'s list of the "Top 7 Most Underrated Games Of Last Generation", with editor Alex Osborn describing it as "One part block puzzle game, the other social simulation, ''Catherine'' is like nothing you've ever played before."<ref>{{cite web |first=Alex |last=Osborn |url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/top-7-most-underrated-games-of-last-generation#/slide/2 |title=Top 7 Most Underrated Games Of Last Generation |page=2 |publisher=[[Game Revolution]] |date=January 12, 2014 |accessdate=June 27, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140822084815/http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/top-7-most-underrated-games-of-last-generation#/slide/2 |archivedate=August 22, 2014 |df= }}</ref> In May 2014, IGN ranked ''Catherine'' sixty-fifth on its "Top 100 Games of a Generation" list, praising its themes, story, and puzzle gameplay before calling it "one of the most refreshingly adult games of this past generation."<ref>{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://www.ign.com/top/games-of-a-generation/65 |title=Catherine - #65 Top Games of a Generation |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=May 20, 2014 |accessdate=June 27, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140602182933/http://www.ign.com/top/games-of-a-generation/65 |archivedate=June 2, 2014 |df= }}</ref> The next month in June 2014, the game placed at number sixty-one on IGN's list of the "Games of a Generation: Your Top 100" as voted by readers of the website.<ref>{{cite web |author=IGN Staff |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/06/04/games-of-a-generation-your-top-100-list?page=1 |title=Games of a Generation: Your Top 100 |page=1 |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=June 4, 2014 |accessdate=June 27, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715182153/http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/06/04/games-of-a-generation-your-top-100-list?page=1 |archivedate=July 15, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
''Catherine'' protagonist Vincent made a cameo appearance in ''Persona 3 Portable'', the [[PlayStation Portable]] remake of ''Persona 3''. The port's female protagonist runs into Vincent, who makes reference to the events of ''Catherine''.<ref name="CathPersonaSil"/> Vincent was included in ''Persona 3 Portable'' as it was created by the same development team as ''Catherine'', but the version of Vincent in ''Persona 3 Portable'' is not the same as that used in ''Catherine''.<ref name="CathPersona3"/> Despite the possibility, staff have discounted the possibility of either an anime adaptation or further games in the series, the latter due to the game's challenging production.<ref name="PSBlogCath"/><ref name="CathNaoki"/> In 2013, Liz Lanier of ''[[Game Informer]]'' included "Catherine / Katherine" among the top ten female villains in video games, stating that "...Vincent can't catch a break between Catherine seducing him one minute and manipulating him the next; Katherine isn't much better with her passive-aggressive push toward marriage. Considering both appear as horrifying boss battles, they can easily be any man's worst nightmare."<ref>{{cite news | title = Top Ten Female Villains | date = November 2013 | work = Game Informer | page= 24 | first = Lix | last = Lanier }}</ref> In 2014, [[David Auerbach]] of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' found ''Catherine'' sexist, writing that its treatment of relationships and sex exemplified a misogynous tendency in [[video game culture]] that became a topic of media discussion over the next several years. According to Auerbach, the game is "a bellwether for what tech culture and gaming have come to mean for a lot of men: a safe playspace from the realities that they believe women force on them."<ref>{{cite news |last= Auerbach |first= David |date= July 24, 2014 |title= The Most Sexist Video Game of All Time? |url= http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/bitwise/2014/07/catherine_video_game_the_most_sexist_platformer_of_all_time.html |newspaper= [[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |location= |publisher= |accessdate= July 25, 2014 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140724170105/http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/bitwise/2014/07/catherine_video_game_the_most_sexist_platformer_of_all_time.html |archivedate= July 24, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
In December 2017, Atlus announced that its Studio Zero division was developing a remaster of the game for the [[PlayStation 4]] and [[PlayStation Vita]], ''Catherine: Full Body'', which will feature new gameplay features, an online mode, a third character as a love interest named Rin, and additional endings and chapters.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Osborn|first1=Alex|title=Catherine: Full Body Announced for PS4, Vita|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2017/12/19/catherine-full-body-announced-for-ps4-vita|website=IGN|accessdate=December 20, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171223130316/http://www.ign.com/articles/2017/12/19/catherine-full-body-announced-for-ps4-vita|archive-date=December 23, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Romano |first1=Sal |title=Catherine: Full Body second trailer, Japanese limited edition and first-print bonus DLC detailed |url=https://gematsu.com/2018/09/catherine-full-body-second-trailer-japanese-limited-edition-and-first-print-bonus-dlc-detailed |website=Gematsu |accessdate=24 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180916055830/https://gematsu.com/2018/09/catherine-full-body-second-trailer-japanese-limited-edition-and-first-print-bonus-dlc-detailed |archive-date=September 16, 2018 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> It will be released in Japan on February 14, 2019, with a Western release planned for sometime after.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Romano |first1=Sal |title=Catherine: Full Body launches February 14, 2019 in Japan |url=https://gematsu.com/2018/09/catherine-full-body-launches-february-14-2019-in-japan |accessdate=September 15, 2018 |work=Gematsu |date=September 12, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180915192609/https://gematsu.com/2018/09/catherine-full-body-launches-february-14-2019-in-japan |archive-date=September 15, 2018 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Strawhun|first1=Aiden|title=PS4 And Vita's Catherine Remake, Full Body, Will Release In The West|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/ps4-and-vitas-catherine-remake-full-body-will-rele/1100-6455797/|website=GameSpot|accessdate=December 22, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222210009/https://www.gamespot.com/articles/ps4-and-vitas-catherine-remake-full-body-will-rele/1100-6455797/|archive-date=December 22, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> {{-}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Fashion Designer |name = Diane Pernet |image = Diane Pernet.jpg |caption = Diane Pernet photographed by Alessandro Simonetti |birth_date = |birth_place = Washington,DC, USA |death_date = |death_place = |residence = Paris |nationality = |education = Temple University |label_name = |occupation = Founder/Director of ASVOFF, fashion blogger and critic }} '''Diane Pernet''' is a [[Paris]]-based [[United States|American-born]] [[France|French]] international [[fashion]] [[blog]]ger and [[critic]]. She is also the founder of [[ASVOFF]] (A Shaded View on Fashion Film).
==Biography== Pernet was born in [[Washington, D.C.]]. She was a [[New York City]] fashion designer in the 1980s, a [[costume designer]] for movies and worked as the women's fashion editor for ''Joyce'' magazine, and as a fashion editor for Elle.com and Vogue.fr. She is the creator of the blog A Shaded View on Fashion (ASVOF) and the Founder and Director of a fashion film festival, A Shaded View on Fashion Film ([[ASVOFF]]).
Pernet has curated CIneOpera, a series of films by the composer/director '''[[Michael Nyman]]''' in 2010 at Corso Como, a fashion/art exhibition and an ASVOFF film program at the New York Art Fair, SCOPE in 2010. She co-curated NOOVO fashion and photography festival in Santiago de Compostela in 2007. On March 30, 2008 she was invited by the Metropolitan Museum in NYC to be on their blog-mode panel and recognized as one of the 3 most influential fashion blogs.
Pernet received a degree in [[documentary]] filmmaking from Temple University<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zoomagazine.de/the_magazine/contributors/ |title=Zoo Magazine |publisher=Zoomagazine.de |date= |accessdate=2011-08-02}}</ref> and she has been making small low-fi movies for years. She also worked as a costume designer for, amongst others, director [[Amos Gitai]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fashionista.com/2010/08/diane-pernet-on-tavi-fashion-film-and-the-future-of-catwalks/ |title=Diane Pernet on Tavi, Fashion Film, and the Future of Catwalks – Fashionista: Fashion Industry News, Designers, Runway Shows, Style Advice |publisher=Fashionista.com |date=2010-08-12 |accessdate=2011-08-02}}</ref>
Designer in the 80’s of her own brand in New York for 13 years, Diane Pernet moved to Paris two decades ago{{when|date=December 2012}} and left the backstage behind to begin a career reporting on fashion. Her first job in Paris was as a costume designer for Amos Gitai's 1992 film Golem l'Esprit d'Exile. Work for the CBC’s Fashion Files programme led to an appointment at Joyce magazine where she was the woman's fashion editor for five years. At Elle.com, she was “Dr. Diane”, who gave style advice, and for Vogue.fr she worked to present the runways.<ref>Diane Pernet 2009 press release, p. 2</ref>
In September 2006, Mark Eley of Eley Kishimoto commissioned her to make a road movie of the brand's men's wear launch and as well as making a documentary film she life-blogged the entire journey from London to Monte Carlo. his film was the impulse behind the launch of Diane's first fashion film festival 'You Wear it Well" which she co-curated with her LA correspondent and was launched in Los Angeles at CineSpace in 2006. In 2008 founded and curated A Shaded View On Fashion Film (ASVOFF) a traveling international event built upon a competition of short fashion, style and beauty films. For its Paris launch, ASVOFF took the form of a festival showcasing feature films, documentaries, conferences, performances and installations<ref>Diane Pernet 2009 press release, p. 9</ref>
Pernet was recognised in 2008 for her pioneering spirit in digital media when she was chosen as one of three influential global bloggers to take part in a panel celebrating a seminal fashion exhibition at New York’s venerated Metropolitan Museum of Art.<ref>http://ashadedviewonfashion.com/about</ref>
Other projects of Diane Pernet included being a talent scout for the Hyères Festival<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/culture/article/2010/04/29/festival-hyeres_1344783_3246.html |title=A Hyères, les belles rencontres de la photographie et de la mode |publisher=LeMonde.fr |date= |accessdate=2011-08-02}}</ref> from 2002-2011, she was the Co-Editor-in-Chief of [[Zoo Magazine]] (Germany) from 2007- April 2012 and in April 2012, she edited one issue of Ninja, a fashion, art and photography magazine that is printed in French and English. Also Pernet has covered fashion for MFF since 2011. She has a special appearance in the Robert Altman film Pret a Porter, Roman Polanski's The Ninth Gate, [[Larry Clark]] The Smell of Us and Ben Stiller's Zoolander 2 which will be released in 2016.
==Personal life== At the age of 28 Diane Pernet married to her first husband Norman, who she has met at the dentist chair.<ref>http://www.coffee-table-stories.com/How-I-Met-My-First-Husband-by-Diane-Pernet</ref> He died in a car accident three years later. After his death, Diane has been married three more times.<ref>http://www.honestby.com/en/news/53/interview-with-dp.html</ref>
==Awards== Pernet is the 2012 recipient of the distinguished FAD Medal from the Barcelona-based cultural institution devoted to the promotion of design and creativity, FAD (Fostering Arts and Design).
Pernet is the recipient of the Felicidad Duce Fashion award in its 13th edition for her extraordinary career as a fashion editor, for pioneering writing about fashion on the internet and becoming leader of bloggers. Also as being the godmother of the world's emerging fashion talent as well as her sensitivity to the film genre that combines art, film and fashion photography. The Escola Superior de Disseny Felicidad Duce Barclona created this award in honor of its founder Ms. Felicidad Duce.The award ceremony is 18 April 2013.[
Pernet was awarded by the President and Executive board of [[Asian Couture Federation]] the Award of Excellence for her outstanding contribution to fashion journalism in September 2014 in Perth, Australia.
Pernet was invited by the School of the Art Institute of Chicago to be their 2015 Legend of Fashion Honoree for her career as a critic, filmmaker and style icon. The ceremony is scheduled on May 8, 2015.
Pernet was accepted into the BOF 500 in 2013 and 2014. As of September 2015, Diane Pernet has been accepted into the Business of Fashion's 500 Hall of Fame, considered their highest honour reserved for those who have demonstrated sustained achievement over the course of their careers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/diane-pernet?collections=3&query=Diane%20Pernet&offset=0|title=Diane Pernet|website=Business of Fashion|access-date=17 April 2018}}</ref>
Pernet was the President of the Forward Fashion Tech Awards by Showroom Prive in 2016
Pernet was awarded Female Style Icon by Fashion Net February 2017 https://www.fashion.net/awards
Pernet was a nominator for the Beazley Designs of the Year 2017. Nominator: Diane Pernet Designer: Aitor Throup
Pernet was awarded THE INSPIRATIONAL–VISIONARY AWARD by BIG October 2018 for her outstanding work in the field of the development of fashion film and her blog, as well as her positive influence on fashion design and art in the region of South East Europe.
== A Shaded View on Fashion == {{BLP unsourced section|date=April 2018}} A Shaded View on Fashion (ASVOF) is the fashion and [[art]] culture [[blog]] of Diane Pernet. She created www.ashadedviewonfashion.com in 2005 “to inspire and be inspired by creation of our times and to propose options”.<ref>Interview with Diane Pernet on the 9th of October in Paris</ref> The ASVOF blog combines photos, drawings, short films, texts and interviews for an inside view on the fashion industry. The readers of the blog are referred to as ‘Shaded Viewers’.
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}} https://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/diane-pernet
== External links == * [http://www.ashadedviewonfashion.com/ AShadedViewOnFashion.com] * [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1161338,00.html Time Magazine: Diane Pernet on Thai fashion designers] * [http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/technology/article2489773.ece The Times: 40 bloggers who really matter] * [http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/life/fashion/article1754436.ece The Times: Bloggers are snapping up front row seats at London Fashion Week] * [http://www.fashionwelike.com/my-style-diane-pernet Diane Pernet talks about her personal style] * [http://www.businessoffashion.com/2014/02/colins-column-the-shaded-lady-diane-pernet.html Collin McDowell: Diane Pernet, The Shaded Lady] * [http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/03/13/q-and-a-diane-pernet-the-original-style-blogger-on-fashion-and-film/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=1 TMagazine: DIane Pernet: The original style blogger on fashion and film] * [http://www.lofficielmode.com/2013/11/27/diane-pernet-interview/ L'Officiel: Diane Pernet: Rencontre avec la grande dame noire de la mode] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MiatuPB7-VI/ Diane Pernet: Blogger Profile] *[http://www.nespresso.com/cannes/wp/?p=936/ Les films de mode avec Diane Pernet] * http://www.vogue.it/bellezza/tendenze-news/2017/10/23/profumo-fondotinta-viaggio-speciale-terme/
{{authority control}}
