{{for|the DVD/CD concert film|I Am... World Tour (album)}} {{Distinguish|I Am Tour (Leona Lewis)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox concert tour | type = World | concert_tour_name = I Am... | image = Beyonce iamtour.jpg | border = | image_size = 220px | artist = [[Beyoncé]] | album = ''[[I Am... Sasha Fierce]]'' | start_date = March 26, 2009 | end_date = February 18, 2010 | number_of_legs = 6 | number_of_shows =47 in Europe
32 in North America
12 in Asia
9 in South America
7 in Oceania
1 in Africa
108 Total | gross = $103.2 million (102 shows) | last_tour = [[The Beyoncé Experience]]
(2007) | this_tour = '''I Am...'''
(2009–10) | next_tour = [[I Am... Yours]]
(2009) }} '''I Am...''' (sometimes referred to as the '''I Am... Tour''' or the '''I Am... World Tour''') was the fourth [[concert tour]] by American recording artist [[Beyoncé]] launched in support of her third studio album, ''[[I Am... Sasha Fierce]]'' (2008). The tour was announced in October 2008 embarked in March 2009 with five rehearsal shows in North America. The tour consisted of 108 shows in total, visiting the Americas, Europe, Asia, Africa, and Australia. Preparations for the shows began eight months prior to the beginning of the tour with twelve-hour rehearsals for two months. Knowles described the shows as her best and most theatrical from all of her tours. The [[set list]] for the concerts included songs from Knowles' three studio albums as well as several covers of other artists and a [[Destiny's Child]] medley. The central theme of the tour was to showcase the difference between Knowles' dual personality; her emotional side and her onstage persona, Sasha Fierce which was also demonstrated in the dual album ''I Am... Sasha Fierce''. The show featured two stages – the main one and a smaller [[B-stage]] where Knowles was transferred during the middle of the show. She was backed by an all-female band, female background dancers and a big [[Light-emitting diode|LED]] screen. [[Thierry Mugler]] collaborated with Knowles on the costumes and had a creative advisor role further working on the [[choreography]], [[lighting]] and production. [[Chris March]] made the costumes usable for stage and helped in their making. For the ballads, Knowles wore longer dresses while for the performances of the up-tempo songs, more make-up and more revealing outfits were worn. The fashion and Knowles' look and figure received praise from critics. I Am... received critical acclaim from [[music journalism|music critics]] who praised Knowles' performance abilities calling her the best female performer. A concert in Malaysia was cancelled by Knowles after several Muslim groups tried to ban it although she agreed to tone down her look according to the country's standards. The tour was commercially successful grossing $86.0 million from 93 shows in total. Separate performances of several songs were broadcast on different channels and two concerts were released as [[live album]]s; the live performance at the [[I Am... Yours]] revue was [[I Am... Yours: An Intimate Performance at Wynn Las Vegas|released]] in a [[CD]]/[[DVD]] format in 2009 and footage of the tour was released on the [[I Am... World Tour (album)|similarly titled live album]] in 2010. ==Background== {{double image|right|I Am... Tour 9.jpg|180|Flickr - gillyberlin - Beyonce I am... Tour 2009 Live in Berlin (48).jpg|180|Knowles performing "[[Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)]]" (''left'') and "[[Diva (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Diva]]" (''right'') during the I Am... tour while being backed by dancers. Both songs were part of the ''Sasha Fierce'' disc on the double album ''I Am... Sasha Fierce'' which was dedicated to her eponymous [[alter ego]].}} In 2006, during an interview with [[MTV News]], Beyoncé introduced an aggressive alter ego, Sasha Fierce, which also served as her stage persona. She added that the persona is a complete opposite of her when not performing by characterizing her as "aggressive... strong... fearless."{{cite news |title=Beyonce Explains 'Fearless' Stage Persona In 2006 Interview |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1627106/beyonce-explains-fearless-stage-persona-2006-interview.jhtml |publisher=[[MTV News]]. [[MTV Networks]] |date=November 25, 2009 |author=Jocelyn Vena |accessdate=March 30, 2011}} Beyoncé's third album ''[[I Am... Sasha Fierce]]'' introduced Sasha Fierce as her alter ego. she revealed that Sasha was born during the making of her single "[[Crazy in Love (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Crazy in Love]]" (2003).{{Cite news |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20241113,00.html |title=Beyoncé 'Still Can't Believe' Justin Was Her Backup Dancer |last=Sullivan |first=Emmet |date=November 18, 2008 |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |accessdate=June 10, 2013}} The plans for a 2009 tour in support of the album were announced in October 2008 by ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1043887/beyonce-eyeing-2009-tour|title=Beyonce Eyeing 2009 Tour|last=Cohen|first=Jonathan|date=October 3, 2008|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=October 9, 2008}} The tour dates for the European leg were announced in December 2008. During an interview with ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', Beyoncé confirmed that she would be backed by the all-female band which had also accompanied her for her previous [[The Beyoncé Experience]] tour (2007). Rehearsals for the tour lasted eight months during which the set list for the shows was also constructed.{{cite web|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/popwatch/2009/03/beyonce-tour.html|title=Beyoncé talks world tour, new videos|date=March 10, 2009|accessdate=March 16, 2009|last=Vozick-Levinson|first=Simon|work=Entertainment Weekly}} Beyoncé further revealed that the twelve-hour rehearsals for the tour included dancing the choreography in heels for two months before it commenced.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/267200/beyonce-the-billboard-qa|title=Beyonce: The Billboard Q&A|work=Billboard|first=Gail|last=Mitchell|date=October 2, 2009|accessdate=June 13, 2013}} During an interview, Beyoncé emphasized how she needed to prepare to channel her alter ego for the performances.{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/music/beyonces-spectacular-i-am--tour-93937|title=Beyonce's spectacular I Am ... tour rolls into Birmingham|work=[[Birmingham Mail]]|date=May 22, 2009|accessdate=June 11, 2013}} According to Beyoncé, the shows were supposed to be a mixture of several of her musical preferences, including [[jazz]], [[Hip hop music|hip-hop]], [[ballet]] and fashion.{{cite web|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/entertainment/beyonces-marathon-tour-taking-toll/story-e6fredpu-1225751787897|title=Beyonce's marathon tour taking toll|work=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]]|first=Jonathon|last=Moran|date=July 19, 2009|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} The tour kicked off in late-March 2009 with five rehearsal shows in North America. It officially commenced in late April 2009, at Arena Zagreb in Croatia later visiting six continents, namely the Americas, Europe, Asia, Africa, and Australia.{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2008/10/15/split-personali/|title=Split personality for new Beyoncé album|date=October 15, 2008|accessdate=October 15, 2008|last=Willman|first=Chris|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/i-am-coming-to-adelaide-beyonce/story-e6freo8c-1225698311698|title=I Am coming to Adelaide|last=MacDonald|first=Patrick|date=April 5, 2009|work=The Advertiser|accessdate=April 5, 2009}} The six-week North American leg of the I Am... tour kicked off on June 21 with a show at [[Madison Square Garden]] in [[New York City|New York]] and finished with a four-night residency at [[Encore Las Vegas|Encore in the Wynn Las Vegas]] from July 30, 2009 to August 2, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1609546/beyonce-announces-us-tour-dates.jhtml|title=Beyonce Announces U.S. Tour Dates|author=Gil Kaufman|date=April 20, 2009|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks|accessdate=March 30, 2011}} The tour finished with a concert at [[Queen's Park Savannah]] in [[Port of Spain]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]], with 108 shows in total. Beyoncé and her organization, The Survivor Foundation, became the spokesperson for [[General Mills]]' [[Hamburger Helper]] campaign entitled, "Show Your Helping Hand".{{cite web|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2009/06/23/beyonce-hamburger-helper/|title=Beyonce fights hunger with Hamburger Helper|work=Entertainment Weekly|last=Simon|first=Vozick-Levinson|date=June 23, 2009|accessdate=June 10, 2013}} The campaign's mission was to provide more than 3.5 million meals to local food banks in North America. Knowles encouraged spectators to bring non-perishable foods to her North American concerts to be donated to the campaign. According to the campaign's official website, nearly three millions meals and over $50,000 have been donated. ==Development== {{double image|left|I Am... Tour 53.jpg|175|I Am... Tour 2.jpg|175|Knowles performing "Smash Into You" (''left'') and "[[Halo (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Halo]]" (''right'') during a stop of the I Am... tour at The O2 Arena in London. The performances saw her singing the songs on a [[stairs|staircase]] which was the largest piece of equipment on stage.}} Beyoncé revealed that the hardest aspect of coming up with the tour's set list was managing to fit her decade-long song catalogue in a two-hour show. According to her, the tour was supposed to be more emotional than The Beyoncé Experience in order to reflect the "real[,] raw and more sensitive" nature of the ''I Am...'' portion of the double album. Beyoncé expressed frustration that snippets of the show appeared online after the first shows on the opening leg, thus "ruining" the surprise factor of the concert experience; however she also appreciated the fact that it can act as a "little sneak peek" for fans to decide if they indeed want to attend. French designer [[Thierry Mugler]] served as the creative advisor while also being responsible for Beyoncé's wardrobe. He contributed in the design of lighting, [[choreography]], production and directed three sequences for the concert.{{cite web|url=http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/news/fashion/289751/thierry-mugler-to-design-beyonce-tour.html|title=Thierry Mugler to design Beyoncé tour|date=December 4, 2008|accessdate=December 28, 2009|work=[[Marie Claire]]|first=Lucy|last=Hutchings|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212082019/http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/news/fashion/289751/thierry-mugler-to-design-beyonce-tour.html|archivedate=December 12, 2009|df=mdy-all}} According to his creative vision, the shows were intended to represent ''[[mise en scène|mise-en-scène]]'' by incorporating technical aspects with fashion in order to capture the emotions behind the songs. He added, "There will be a lot of dramatization and metamorphosis on stage. Some very strong effects have been inspired directly by Beyoncé, and only she could make [them] happen on stage." Onstage, Beyoncé was backed by her ten-piece all-female band, Suga Mama, which included two [[drummer]]s, two [[keyboardist]]s, a percussionist, a [[horn section]], three backup vocalists called the Mamas, and a lead [[guitarist]]. The show featured two stages, namely a simple main stage with a pop0up set of stairs, an [[Light-emitting diode|LED]] background screen, and glass risers for Suga Mama and The Mamas as well as a smaller [[B-stage]] in the midst of the audience for the later portions of the show. During the concerts, Beyoncé went through six costume changes; during the breaks, The Mamas harmonized. The [[set list]] included songs from all of Beyoncé's three studio albums that had been published, a [[Destiny's Child]] medley and several covers of other artists. Several critics noted that the songs on the set list were divided into ballads and more up-tempo songs to coincide with the central theme of ''I Am... Sasha Fierce'' – the dual personality of Beyoncé. Beyoncé's costumes were changed in order to coincide with the songs' nature; during performances of ballads, she wore longer white dresses while for the uptempo songs, she had more revealing outfits and make-up. ==Fashion== [[File:Thierry mugler design sketches.jpg|right|180px|thumb|Thierry Mugler design sketches for the wardrobe of the I Am... tour. The words "Feminine. Free. Warrior. Fierce" were used as inspiration for the look during the concerts.]] Thierry Mugler served as the main [[costume designer]] for the tour. Beyoncé was acquainted to and enraptured by his work at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art|Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute]] Gala, titled "Superheroes, Fashion and Fantasy" (2008) where she saw several of his [[haute couture]] pieces that were on display. Beyoncé discussed the possibility of using the costumes with [[Tina Knowles]].{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/life/article/Thierry-Mugler-re-creates-Beyonce-as-a-fierce-diva-1741497.php|title=Thierry Mugler re-creates Beyonce as a fierce diva|work=[[San Antonio Express-News]] ''via'' [[Houston Chronicle]]|first=Michael|last=Quintanilla|date=April 29, 2009|accessdate=June 10, 2013}} She met with Mugler in Paris in September of the same year and started exchanging ideas for costume designs and the following month he was contracted as the designer for the tour. While designing, the main concept Mugler wanted to illustrate was the duality between "being a woman and a warrior" through his own creative perception; the words "Feminine. Free. Warrior. Fierce" were the overarching inspiration.{{cite web|first=Bridget|last=Folley|url=http://www.wwd.com/fashion-news/mugler-for-beyonce-woman-meets-warrior-2082354 |title=Mugler for Beyoncé: Woman Meets Warrior – Fashion and Design News and Trends |work=[[Women's Wear Daily]]| date=March 26, 2009 |accessdate=December 3, 2009}} He felt, "Sasha Fierce is another aspect of Beyoncé's personality, she is Fierce on stage and Beyoncé in real life... Beyoncé is a very sophisticated 'stage animal', which means that she is truly instinctive. Beyoncé expresses herself through the two aspects of her personality." Furthermore, the elaborate costumes were related to the meanings of the songs performed. A seventy one piece wardrobe was designed for Beyoncé and her dancers and band. For the shows, Beyoncé adopted ten different looks. American fashion designer [[Chris March]] also worked with Mugler ensuring the costumes were suitable for stage purposes. On July 23, 2009, March filed a lawsuit against Mugler for allegedly not paying him for the work he did on the wardrobe.{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2009/08/christ_march_sues_theirry_mugl.html|title=Chris March Is Suing Thierry Mugler Over Beyoncé's Costumes|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|first=Amy|last=Odell|date=August 28, 2009|accessdate=June 12, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/news/141470/project-runway-all-star-sues-over-beyonce-s-tour-togs|title=NEWS/ Project Runway All-Star Sues Over Beyoncé's Tour Togs|publisher=[[E! Online]]. [[NBCUniversal]]|first1=Gina|last1=Serpe|first2=Whitney|last2=English|first3=Lindsay|last3=Miller|date=August 27, 2009|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} Metal pieces, fishnets, gloves, power shoulders and golden leotards were all incorporated in the costumes, the majority of which were form-fitting and exposed the singer's legs.{{cite web|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/musicnightlife/2008971694_zmus02beyonce.html|title=Concert review | At the Key, Beyoncé put a style on it|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|first=Joanna|last=Horowitz|date=April 2, 2009|accessdate=June 15, 2013}} Michael Quintanilla of ''[[San Antonio Express-News]]'' thought the fashion was akin to a "high-tech ''[[Blade Runner]]'' world". For the performance of several songs, Beyoncé also wore leopard-print pants and [[Radioluminescence|glow-in-the-dark]] bra with a blinking beacon affixed to her body. The fashion and Beyoncé's look during the shows received praise from critics. Randall King of the ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'' noted that the fashion was inspired by "1970s space movie" fashion by [[Bob Mackie]]. Alice Jones of ''[[The Independent]]'' noted: "[the list of] 30 songs introduces us to any number of different Beyoncés – [[showgirl]], balladeer, [[feminism|feminist]], rock chick, gangster queen, [[cyborg]] – via off-stage costume changes and a leotard for every mood". Kathy McCabe of ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]'' noted that the shows featured "some of the most elaborate and revealing costumes of her career" thus far.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/beyonce-knowles-loves-to-put-the-booty-on/story-e6frexar-1225703079383|title=Beyonce Knowles loves to put the booty on|date=April 24, 2009|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]|first=Kathy|last=McCabe|accessdate=November 29, 2011}} A writer of the ''[[Evening Chronicle]]'' wrote that the sparkling outfits managed to capture the singer's personality with looks ranging from "[[New York City Police Department|NYPD cop]] to bride to [[Wonder Woman|Wonderwoman]] and beyond" all the while emphasizing her physique. Holly Burnes of ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]'' also praised the fashion writing that the singer's look included "one incredible costume after another: from a [[Mad Max]] look... to an angelic wedding dress Jay Hanna of ''[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|The Sunday Times]]'' compared Beyoncé's look to a goddess, particularly with the costume she wore for "[[Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.perthnow.com.au/entertainment/beyonce-knowles-wows-perth-fans-at-burswood-concert/story-e6frg3ic-1225779313174 |title=Beyonce Knowles wows Perth fans at Burswood concert |work=[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|The Sunday Times]] |date=September 25, 2009 |first=Jay |last=Hanna |accessdate=June 15, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616081529/http://www.perthnow.com.au/entertainment/beyonce-knowles-wows-perth-fans-at-burswood-concert/story-e6frg3ic-1225779313174 |archivedate=June 16, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} ==Concert synopsis== {{double image|left|Flickr - anniepoes - Intro.jpg|200|I Am... Tour.jpg|180|Beyoncé pictured during the opening and the closing sequence of the show. During the beginning of the concert, she appeared on stage surrounded by smoke and struck a pose in silhouette (''left''). The final of the show saw Knowles on top of a staircase repeatedly saying "I am", awaiting the crowd to say it back (''right'').}} The show started with Beyoncé's silhouette appearing on a smoky stage, walking towards the front while singing several lines of "[[Déjà Vu (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Déjà Vu]]". Dressed in a gold leotard and stilettos, she was quickly joined by two dancers in catsuits proceeding to perform "Crazy in Love"; during the performance of the song glitter and [[confetti]] were dropped on stage. "[[Naughty Girl (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Naughty Girl]]" was performed next as bright orange lights were displayed on stage.{{cite web|url=http://www.musicomh.com/reviews/live/beyonc-o2-arena-london|title=Live Reviews – Beyoncé @ O2 Arena, London|work=[[musicOMH]]|first=Michael|last=Cragg|date=November 15, 2009|accessdate=June 15, 2013}} For the performance of "[[Freakum Dress]]", Beyoncé was accompanied by a guitarist onstage, bending backwards during the song's bridge. "[[Get Me Bodied]]" followed, for which the singer was engaging in elaborate dance routines with her background dancers.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/review/268304/beyonce-june-21-2009-new-york-madison-square-garden|title=Beyonce / New York (Madison Square Garden)|date=June 21, 2009|work=Billboard|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} Following a short break, Beyoncé proceeded singing songs from the ''I Am...'' portion of the album, dressed in a white leotard. "Smash Into You" was performed on top of a flight of stairs. For "[[Ave Maria (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Ave Maria]]", her background dancers turned her white dress into a wedding gown by attaching a veil to her head.{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2010/12/video_rare_behind_the_scenes_f.html|title=Video: Rare Behind-the-Scenes Footage of Beyoncé Working With Thierry Mugler on Her Tour Costumes|work=New York|publisher=New York Media, LLC|first=Amy|last=Odell|date=December 14, 2010|accessdate=June 15, 2013}} Excerpts of [[Sarah McLachlan]]'s "[[Angel (Sarah McLachlan song)|Angel]]" and [[Franz Schubert]]'s [[Ellens dritter Gesang|Ave Maria]]" were performed at the end. She continued on to sing "[[Broken-Hearted Girl]]" wearing a white bustier with a sheer, flowing wrap. Outtakes from the music video of "[[If I Were a Boy]]" were Beyoncé appeared to perform the aforementioned song dressed as a cop wearing [[Ray-Ban]]s and a leather breastplate.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1614410/beyonce-jay-z-thrill-new-york-crowd-at-i-stop.jhtml|title=Beyonce, Jay-Z Thrill New York Crowd At ''I Am...'' Stop|work=MTV News|first=Jayson|last=Rodriguez|date=June 22, 2009|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} Excerpts from [[Alanis Morissette]]'s "[[You Oughta Know]]" and [[Tupac Shakur]]'s "[[California Love]]" were incorporated in the middle of the song.Music World Entertainment (2010) Beyoncé – ''I Am... World Tour'' (Liner Notes) Columbia Records. A video interlude directed by [[Melina Matsoukas]] was shown set to "[[Sweet Dreams (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Sweet Dreams]]". The video showed a robotic Beyoncé interacting with a cheetah as a mechanical voice intoned Sasha Fierce. Beyoncé then appeared on stage dressed in a leopard-print leotard to perform "[[Diva (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Diva]]". She appeared at the top of the staircase with her backup female dancers; a video interlude showing a five-year old Beyoncé singing and dancing was shown in the middle of the song. She then sang "[[Radio (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Radio]]" while the clip of her dancing as ac child was still projected on the screen. "[[Me, Myself and I (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Me, Myself and I]]" was introduced with a brief speech about female empowerment. "[[Ego (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Ego]]" and "Hello" were performed afterwards. {{double image|right|Flickr - smilesea - Beyoncé Newcastle 2009 (11).jpg|185|Flickr - gillyberlin - Beyonce I am... Tour 2009 Live in Berlin (24).jpg|185|Knowles being lifted with a harness during the performance of "[[Baby Boy (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Baby Boy]]" (''left'') and transported to a B-stage where she performed several songs near the audience (''right'').}} The show continued with a short medley performed by her backup singers, The Mamas, followed by another video interlude, featuring Sasha Fierce.{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/music/index.ssf/2009/06/beyonce_captivates_on_a_tour_f.html |title=Beyonce captivates on a tour full of theatrics |work=[[New Jersey On-Line]] |first=Jay |last=Lustig |date=June 22, 2009 |accessdate=June 15, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65sBtq5uF?url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/music/index.ssf/2009/06/beyonce_captivates_on_a_tour_f.html |archivedate=March 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} Beyoncé appeared on stage after a gong bang; she was lifted out of a 20-foot train by a harness and performed "[[Baby Boy (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Baby Boy]]" while high-stepping and front-flipping above the audience. She was then lowered to the B-stage where she finished the song and continued with a cover [[Dawn Penn]]'s "[[You Don't Love Me (No, No, No)]]". A stripped-down version of "[[Irreplaceable]]" was sung afterwards with frequent crowd interactions. Beyoncé then continued with "[[Check On It]]" and a medley of [[Destiny's Child]] hits including "[[Bootylicious]]", "[[Jumpin' Jumpin']]", "[[Independent Women]]", "[[Bills, Bills, Bills]]" and "[[Survivor (Destiny's Child song)|Survivor]]". Performances of "[[Upgrade U]]" and "[[Video Phone (song)|Video Phone]]" followed. For the performance of the two songs, Beyoncé was accompanied by two female dancers and three male dancers, one of whom recorded a live stream of her with a camera throughout the routine during the performance of the latter song. This was followed by a rendition of "[[Say My Name]]" where she interacted with members of the audience, asking them to say her name. The concert followed back at the main stage where for the penultimate section, Beyoncé appeared wearing a gown and singing "[[At Last]]". A footage of her performance of the song at [[Barack Obama]]'s inauguration as [[President of the United States]], video images of [[civil and political rights|civil rights]] era footage and snippets from her performance of the song in the movie, ''[[Cadillac Records]]'' (2008) were shown on the screen behind here. "[[Listen (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Listen]]" was performed afterwards. This was followed by a [[YouTube]] video interlude featuring imitations of the choreography of "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" performed by fans as well as Barack Obama and [[Justin Timberlake]]. Beyoncé then performed the song's trademark choreography accompanied by two female back-up dancers. For the finale, an extended version of "[[Halo (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Halo]]" was performed while the singer descended from the stage to shake hands with fans in the front rows. She then went to the top of the staircase and repeatedly said "I am", awaiting the crowd to say it back. The letters "I am... yours" were displayed on the screen as she exited the stage. ==Critical response== {{quote box|width=23em|align=right|quote=Beyonce's entrance at the O2 makes the finale of '[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]' seem like an exercise in tasteful understatement. As dry ice gusts wildly about the stage and [[Richard Wagner|Wagnerian]] horns blare, a statuesque silhouette appears, hand on hips, head tilted imperiously. Then the swelling intro to 'Crazy In Love' kicks in, the smoke clears, and there stands Beyonce, superhumanly buff and glamorous. You are left in no doubt that tonight you are in the presence of pop royalty ... There's so much glittering spectacle that you could be at a lavish [[Broadway theatre|Broadway musical]] or a presidential inauguration ... Pop music doesn't get any smarter, sassier or more spectacular. |source=—Nick Kelly, ''[[Irish Independent]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/beyonce-puts-on-a-dazzling-display-at-the-o2-26540381.html|title=Beyonce puts on a dazzling display at the O2|work=[[Irish Independent]]|first=Nick|last=Kelly|date=June 1, 2009|accessdate=June 15, 2013}}}} The tour received rave reviews from critics. Mike Ross of the website [[Jam!]] rated Beyoncé's performance with 4.5 out of 5 stars, praising the "high-production", the singer's wide vocal range and her "riveting presence".{{cite web|title=Rexall Place, Edmonton|date=March 26, 2009|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/B/Beyonce/ConcertReviews/2009/03/27/8904821-sun.html|last=Ross|first=Mike|publisher=[[Jam!]]. [[Sun Media]]|accessdate=June 13, 2013}} Stephanie Classen of ''[[The Star Phoenix]]'' remarked, "Beyoncé doesn't really need the bells and whistles of a big stadium show, but it sure makes for an unforgettable concert." Randall King of the ''Winnipeg Free Press'' graded the tour 4 stars out of 5 and praised the "back and forth" switch between the double persona throughout the show with the singer exhibiting both "raw energy" and "feeling"-induced ballads.{{cite web|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/entertainment/music/part-vamp-part-demure----all-beyonce-42072442.html|title=Part vamp, part demure – all Beyoncé|date=March 29, 2009|accessdate=March 31, 2009|last=King|first=Randall|work=[[Winnipeg Free Press]]}} Alice Jones of ''The Independent'' emphasized how the singer managed to "sing her heart out" in various musical styles that characterze the show's songs while further praising the energetic choreography and the vocals that range from "caramel smooth to honeyed foghorn". She concluded her review by saying, "Watching Beyoncé sing and strut her stuff can feel at best overawing, at worst, alienating".{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Alice |title=Beyoncé, 02 Arena, London:Diva who answers the call of booty |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/beyonc-02-arena-london-1691069.html |work=[[The Independent]]|date=May 27, 2009|accessdate=May 23, 2009}} Ben Ratliff of ''The New York Times'' observed that the show would make spectators question themselves how the singer managed to put on a "dazzling show" both physically and organizationally; he further praised the singer's "hollering voice, her imperious movement, her costume changes and the show's crush of concepts with their long tails of reference".{{cite news|last=Ratliff|first=Ben |title=Flash, Concepts and, Yes, Songs|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/23/arts/music/23beyonce.html |work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 22, 2009|accessdate=May 23, 2009}} Deborah Mcaleese and Lauren Mulvenny of ''[[The Belfast Telegraph]]'' described the show as "incredible... mind blowing... [and] electrifying".{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/news/in-pictures-beyonc-in-belfast-28496556.html|title=In Pictures: Beyoncé in Belfast|work=[[The Belfast Telegraph]]|first1=Deborah|last1=Mcaleese|first2=Lauren|last2=Mulvenny|date=June 1, 2009|accessdate=June 15, 2013}} A writer of ''[[Evening Chronicle]]'' wrote that the show's set abounded with "bling, glamour and, most importantly, enthusiasm", further praising her for the well-coordinated balance between "hit[ting] every note" and following elaborate choreographies.{{cite news|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/review-beyonce-newcastle-metro-radio-1454916 |title=Review: Beyonce at Newcastle Metro Radio Arena |work=[[Evening Chronicle]] |date=May 23, 2009 |accessdate=June 15, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402160046/http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/review-beyonce-newcastle-metro-radio-1454916 |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |df= }} Jay Hanna of ''The Sunday Times'' felt that the show's encore ("Halo") was the most memorable moment of the set. She also praised the singer's "enviable" dancing skills, "spectacular production and audio visuals" but noted that some songs "let down" the performance by being less melodic. Jay Lustig of ''The Star-Ledger'' described the show as a "bona fide pop spectacle" with futuristic themes throughout. Jim Farber from the ''Daily News'' viewed the tour as "a huge upgrade in charm, humor and chops" as compared to [[The Beyoncé Experience]] and added that "Beyoncé's presence punctuated her singing like an exclamation point". Describing the show as simultaneously "spellbinding, exhausting to watch and hugely slick", Michael Cragg of [[musicOMH]] noted that the highlights included songs from the ''Sasha Fierce'' half of the album. Caryn Ganz of ''Rolling Stone'' magazine praised the show, lauding the singer for her work ethic and the ability to execute singing, dancing and posing at the same time. Jayson Rodriguez of MTV News, commented "Through six outfit changes, bombastic ballads, high-energy singles and a daring high-wire journey from the stage to the center of the arena, Beyoncé delivered over and over again." A writer of ''Billboard'' magazine noted that Knowles "brought all the fierceness" on stage for the tour. ''[[The Australian]]''{{'}}s Patrick Emery noted that Knowles showcased her self-assurance and professionalism in "full view".{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/archive/arts-arc/choreographed-self-belief/story-e6frg8po-1225775188653|title=Choreographed self-belief|work=[[The Australian]]|first=Patrick|last=Emery|date=September 17, 2009|accessdate=June 15, 2013}} Comparing her performance with [[Michael Jackson]]'s live shows, Renee Michelle Harris of the ''South Florida Times'' writes, "[Knowles] owns the stage with her trademark swagger and intensity... showcasing her powerful vocals without missing a note, often while engaged in vigorous, perfectly executed dance moves".{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Renee Michelle|title=Beyoncé Wows Crowd at BankAtlantic Center|url=http://www.sfltimes.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2977&Itemid=1 |work=South Florida Times|date=July 3, 2009|accessdate=July 3, 2009}} Holly Burnes of ''The Daily Telegraph'' noted that the performance was almost inimitable and added "Whether crumping, sweeping across the stage in towering heels, or simply standing still, Beyonce was dynamite, blasting the benchmark for concert performers forever".{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/beyonce-knowles-and-sasha-fierce-unite-sydney-ladies-fans-at-concert/story-e6frexar-1225776869209|title=Beyonce Knowles and Sasha Fierce unite Sydney ladies, fans at concert|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]|first=Holly|last=Burnes|date=September 19, 2009|accessdate=June 15, 2013}} Simon Colling from ''The West Australian'' described the performance as "powerhouse" and added, "Beyonce's high-energy, high-voltage mix of song (loud, commercial R&B) and dance recalled names like Tina Turner, [[Aretha Franklin]] and rapper [[Missy Elliott]]... [and] [[Mariah Carey]]". Joanna Horowitz of ''The Seattle Times'' noted that despite the inclusion of almost 10 different musical styles in the show's set list, the singer's "own [musical] signature" and focus were lacking. Nevertheless, Horowitz praised the singer's performing skills and summarized the concert as "a hip-hop [[Cirque du Soleil]] — sequins galore, dramatic dance numbers, and Beyoncé at one point soaring". ''[[The Observer]]''{{'}}s Barbara Ellen wrote, "she is a force of nature – delivering one of the most enjoyable well-paced shows I've seen in years".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/may/24/beyonce|title=She's a woman of two halves|work=[[The Observer]]|first=Barbara|last=Ellen|date=May 24, 2009|accessdate=June 15, 2013}} However, she noted that Knowles is "so steeped in professionalism that what should be magical can become mechanical." Noting influences by [[Tina Turner]] and [[Barbra Streisand]] during the tour, Ann Powers of ''Los Angeles Times'' writes: "And she danced like only Beyonce can dance, with a combination of power, grace and smarts that fully unites Broadway choreography with urban street innovations ... Indeed, her production can be seen as a retelling of pop's history from a feminine viewpoint -- and as an argument for Beyonce as the ultimate realization of the female pop dream."{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/jul/13/entertainment/et-beyonce13|title=Pop Music Review – Live: Beyoncé at Honda Center|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|first=Ann|last=Powers|authorlink=Ann Powers|date=July 13, 2009|accessdate=June 15, 2013}} Ben Ratliff of ''[[The New York Times]]'' summarized the tour's concept as "the duality of well-meaning good girl and rapacious animal-robot-dance-titan." Jay Lustig of ''[[The Star-Ledger]]'' concluded that the album's split personality was reflected in the show naturally enough. However, Barbara Ellen of ''[[The Observer]]'' wrote, "Another irritant is the much-trumpeted 'duality' nonsense with Sasha Fierce, Beyoncé's alter-ego for her latest album. All 'Sasha' does here is flail about in a video, no different from regular Beyoncé, except for a gold dress and a hairdo that veers dangerously towards Liberace." Similarly, [[Ann Powers]] from the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote that the only thing which was not fully realized was the show's "overarching" theme, "Beyonce meant to represent herself as a split personality, tender and open on the one hand, indomitable and rather scary on the other. But Beyonce has chosen the wrong dichotomy to represent herself." ==Commercial performance== Tickets for the American leg of the tour were available for pre-sale for members of Knowles' fan club on April 20, 2008 and the official tickets went on sale to the general public through [[Ticketmaster]] on April 25. In late May 2009, Knowles' label announced through a press release that the singer decided to set aside 2,000 seats for each date on her then-forthcoming North American tour at a discounted price of $20.{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2009/04/17/beyonce-announces-us-tour-dates/|title=Beyoncé Announces U.S. Tour Dates|work=[[Rap-Up]]|date=April 17, 2009|accessdate=June 14, 2013}} After already selling 1,000 tickets per show for the special low price, the last 1,000 discounted seats for each show were made available to the public on May 29, 2009 through [[Ticketmaster]] (with the exception of the artist's four-night residency at the Encore at Wynn Las Vegas).{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1612293/beyonce-offering-20-tickets-upcoming-tour.jhtml|title=Beyonce Offering $20 Tickets For Upcoming Tour|first=Daniela|last=Capistrano|date=May 28, 2009|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks|accessdate=March 30, 2011}} Due to the big demand, Sony Music announced additional dates in England, Asia and South America. In May 2009, Knowles' official website was peppered with requests by disappointed fans — from Boston; Anchorage, Alaska; Tampa, Florida; St. Louis and Montreal — who asked from her to come to their towns. The ''Daily Mail'' reported that the first European leg of the tour sold over 350,000 tickets for 32 shows; the UK part of the leg sold out completely with Knowles playing to over 100,000 fans.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1204797/Beyonc-adds-extra-dates-UK-Ireland-I-AM--tour.html|title=Beyoncé adds extra November dates for UK and Ireland 'I Am...' tour|work=Daily Mail|date=August 6, 2009|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} Knowles broke her record of concert attendees by selling out the [[Morumbi Stadium]] in [[São Paulo]], Brazil, with over 60,000 tickets sold.{{cite web|url=http://www.beyonceonline.com/us/news/brazil-concert-announcement |title=Beyoncé Triumphs In Brazil Without Reported Incident|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301004513/http://www.beyonceonline.com/us/news/brazil-concert-announcement|archivedate=March 1, 2012 |publisher=Beyonceonline.com |date=February 12, 2010 |accessdate=August 27, 2010}} It was reported to ''Billboard'' that as of September 16, 2009, from the 53 shows, Knowles grossed $53.5 million and drawn 667,509 fans from the mostly 15,000-seat arenas.{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EX4yD1pJCxUC&pg=RA1-PA38&dq=The+Beyonc%C3%A9+Experience+tour+boxscore&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HPOyUevqHOmw7Ab3sIHQAw&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=The%20Beyonc%C3%A9%20Experience%20tour%20boxscore&f=false|title=Taking It Onstage|work=Billboard|first=Mariel|last=Concepcion|page=38|volume=121|number=39|date=October 3, 2009|issn=0006-2510|accessdate=June 8, 2013}} In 2009, the tour was nominated for Eventful Fans' Choice Award at the 6th Annual [[Billboard Touring Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.billboardevents.com/billboardevents/photos/stylus/148481-2009touringawards.pdf|title=''Billboard'' Touring 2009 Awards|accessdate=December 28, 2009|work=Billboard|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122115122/http://www.billboardevents.com/billboardevents/photos/stylus/148481-2009touringawards.pdf|archivedate=November 22, 2010 }} The tour grossed $86 million from 93 concert shows{{cite web|url=http://www.pollstarpro.com/SpecialFeatures2009/2009YearEndTop50WorldwideConcertTours.pdf|title=2009 Year End Top 50 Worldwide Concert Tours|work=[[Pollstar]]|accessdate=December 3, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pollstarpro.com/specialfeatures2010/2010MidYearTop50WorldwideTours.pdf|title=2010 Mid End Top 50 Worldwide Concert Tours|work=Pollstar|year=2010|accessdate=September 7, 2010}} and 108 show total grossed $119,5 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/meghancasserly/2012/12/10/beyonce-knowles-50-million-pepsi-deal-takes-creative-cues-from-jay-z/|title=Beyoncé's $50 Million Pepsi Deal Takes Creative Cues From Jay Z|work=[[Forbes]]|publisher=Forbes publishing|first=Meghan|last=Casserly|date=December 10, 2012|accessdate=April 9, 2013}} ==Controversy in Malaysia== {{double image|left|I Am... Tour 25.jpg|200|Flickr - anniepoes - Broken-Hearted Girl.jpg|180|Knowles on tour. For the performances of "[[If I Were a Boy]]" (''left'') she wore futuristic designs and heralded the arrival of her onstage persona while a white dress was designed for the performances of "[[Broken-Hearted Girl]]" (''right'') and other ballads to show her emotional side.}} In September 2009, it was announced by the Associated Press that Knowles would be bringing her show to [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] on October 25, 2009, but it would be without some of her usual tricks. After encountering what became familiar opposition from religious groups in a predominantly Muslim country, Knowles agreed to tone down some parts of her act. A spokesperson for the [[Pan-Malaysian Islamic Party]] stated: "We are against Western sexy performances; we don't think our people need that." However, a rep soon came from the concert's Malaysian organizer, stating that "all parties have reached an amicable understanding" about the performance. He went on saying that Knowles should be regarded as a "role model" and an "embodiment of success" because of her philanthropic work, including campaigns against poverty and domestic violence. The Marctensia promoter further told the Associated Press: "We are confident that Beyoncé's concert will once and for all silence international critics and put Malaysia back on track and move up the ranks in presenting A-list international pop concerts in this region and further boost tourism."{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1622241/beyonce-agrees-tone-down-concert-malaysian-date.jhtml|title=Beyonce Agrees To Tone Down Concert For Malaysian Date|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks|first=Matt|last=Thompson|date=September 24, 2009|accessdate=January 30, 2012}} However, it was ultimately announced in October 2009 that the concert has been postponed in the wake of accusations by Islamic conservatives that the show would be "immoral and unclean".{{cite web|url=http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/news/398075/beyonc-branded-immoral-by-malay-muslims.html|title=Beyoncé Branded 'Immoral' by Malay Muslims|work=[[Marie Claire]]|accessdate=June 15, 2013}} Malaysian promoter Marctensia said in a statement that the show has been postponed to a future date to be announced shortly, and added "The postponement is solely [the] decision of the artist and has nothing to with other external reasons." Another representative declined to comment on whether the show was postponed due to the heavy criticism it was receiving from religious leaders in the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1624205/beyonces-malaysian-concert-postponed-again.jhtml|title=Beyonce's Malaysian Concert Postponed Again|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks|first=Matt|last=Thompson|date=October 19, 2009|accessdate=January 30, 2012}} The show also faced oppositions by Islamic conservatives in Egypt who branded it as an "insolent sex party" that threatens the Muslim nation's "social peace and stability" and tried to encourage people against going to the concert.{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2009-11-05-beyonce-egypt_N.htm|title=Islamic critics call Beyonce tour 'insolent sex party'|work=''[[Associated Press]] via'' [[USA Today]]|date=November 5, 2009|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} Two years prior to the performance, Knowles scheduled a show in Malaysia but backed out due to similar protests regarding her performance.{{cite web |url=http://uk.eonline.com/news/56323/beyonc-calls-off-booty-bottling-concert|title=Beyoncé Calls Off Booty-Bottling Concert|publisher=E! Online. NBCUniversal|first=Gina|last=Serpe|date=October 1, 2007|accessdate=June 7, 2013}} ==Recordings and broadcasts== [[File:Beyoncé e Jay-Z.jpg|thumb|200px|Knowles performing "Crazy in Love" with Jay-Z during the I Am... tour stop at The O2 arena in London]] {{Main article|I Am... Yours: An Intimate Performance at Wynn Las Vegas|I Am... World Tour (album)}} While Knowles was on tour, she was asked to perform a [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] residency-type of show.{{cite video | people=Knowles, Beyoncé (Performer)| date=November 23, 2009 | title=I Am... Yours: An Intimate Performance at Wynn Las Vegas| medium=concert | location=Las Vegas, Nevada | publisher=Splinter Films, Ltd}} Knowles and her team produced the shows in seven days and entitled it [[I Am... Yours]]. She performed an unplugged, acoustic styled show different from the rest of her tour, at the [[Encore Las Vegas|Encore Theater]] in Las Vegas.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mike-ragogna/emhuffpost-reviewsem-beyo_b_367138.html|title=HuffPost Reviews: Beyonce, Rihanna, Buddy Holly, The Doors, Susan Boyle, and More|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|first=Mike|last=Ragogna|date=November 23, 2009|accessdate=February 5, 2012}} The show on August 2, 2009 was recorded and later released as a DVD, audio CD and television special in late November 2009 titled ''[[I Am... Yours: An Intimate Performance at Wynn Las Vegas]]''.{{cite press release |title=Music World Music/Columbia Records Set To Release "I Am... Yours An Intimate Performance At Wynn Las Vegas"...|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/music-world-musiccolumbia-records-set-to-release-i-am-yours-an-intimate-performance-at-wynn-las-vegas-an-extraordinary-concert-performance-dvd-and-live-cd-from-iconic-superstar-beyonce-68436217.html |publisher=[[PR Newswire]]. PR Newswire Association LLC |date=November 2, 2009 |accessdate=December 28, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/11/turkey-with-beyonc%C3%A9-rb-star-scores-thanksgiving-special.html|title=Turkey with Beyonce: R&B star scores Thanksgiving special|work=Los Angeles Times|first=Todd|last=Martens|date=November 1, 2009|accessdate=June 11, 2013}} The DVD was commercially successful peaking at number one on the [[Nielsen ratings|Nielsen SoundScan Music DVD]] chart.{{cite web |url=http://www.trueclef.wordpress.com/2011/01/13/beyonces-i-am-tour-is-best-selling-tour-dvd-of-2010/ |title=Beyonce's "I Am" Tour Is Best Selling Tour DVD of 2010!!! |publisher=Trueclefmusic.com |accessdate=August 16, 2014}} It was certified double platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA).{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS |title=Searchable Database |publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] |accessdate=January 1, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150329084033/http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS |archivedate=March 29, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} Another live CD/DVD of the tour was released as ''[[I Am... World Tour (album)|I Am... World Tour]]'' in late November 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1652994/beyonce-jokes-shes-been-pregnant-with-concert-special.jhtml |title=Beyonce Jokes She's Been Pregnant With Concert Special|first=Jocelyn|last=Vena|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks|date=November 24, 2010|accessdate=January 24, 2012}} The album contained performances from different stops of the tour blended with personal footage of Knowles' backstage work and thoughts about the tour and her life.{{cite press release|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/music-worldcolumbia-records-releasing-beyonces-i-amworld-tour-the-new-full-length-dvd-concert-film-experience-produced-directed--edited-by-beyonce-for-her-own-parkwood-pictures-106424558.html|title=Music World/Columbia Records Releasing Beyonce's I Am...World Tour, The New Full-Length DVD|location=New York|publisher=PR Newswire PR Newswire Association LLC|date=November 1, 2010|accessdate=June 25, 2013}} It served as the directorial debut for Knowles.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a289371/beyonce-excited-by-directorial-debut.html|title=Beyoncé "excited" by directorial debut|first=Robert|last=Copsey|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]. [[Hachette Filipacchi Médias]]|date=November 23, 2010|accessdate=June 26, 2013}} The DVD was commercially successful becoming the best selling DVD in the world in 2010.{{cite press release|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/beyonces-i-amworld-tour-full-length-concert-film-named-the-best-selling-music-dvd-of-2010-113206414.html|title=Beyonce's I Am...World Tour Full-length Concert Film Named the Best-selling Music DVD of 2010|location=New York|publisher=Columbia Records/Music World|date=January 10, 2011|accessdate=June 26, 2013}} Parts of the show in [[Vancouver]] on March 31, 2009 were recorded and have been used for commercial use, as well as photos from the show used in the official tour book and other promotional items. "If I Were A Boy" and "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" from the show in [[New Orleans]] were recorded and shown on [[TV One (US TV network)|TV One]] as a part of the [[Essence Music Festival]] in 2009.{{Cite episode|title=2009 Essence Music Festival|episodelink=Essence Music Festival|network=[[TV One (US TV network)|TV One]]|date=September 2009|location=US}} A CD and DVD, released on June 15, 2010, featured her performance of "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)".{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Essence-Music-Festival-15th-Anniversary/dp/B003L1954W|title=Essence Music Festival 15th Anniversary 2.1 CD/DVD|publisher=Amazon.com (US). Amazon Inc|accessdate=June 26, 2013}} "Crazy In Love", "Freakum Dress", "Get Me Bodied", "Smash Into You" and "Broken-Hearted Girl" from the show in [[Donetsk]], [[Ukraine]], were recorded professionally and shown on [[Television in Ukraine|TRK Ukraina]] as part of their footage of the [[Donbass Arena]] opening.{{Cite episode|title=Donbass Arena|location=Donetsk, Ukraine|network=Television in Ukraine|year=2009}} "Crazy In Love" and "Single Ladies" were professionally recorded at the [[Summer Sonic Festival]] in [[Osaka]], Japan and used to promote Knowles' Japanese tour.{{Cite episode|title=2009 Summer Sonic Festival|episodelink=Summer Sonic Festival|location=Japan|date=August 2009}} "Crazy In Love" and "Naughty Girl" were also professionally recorded at the [[2009 Singapore Grand Prix]] F1 Rocks event in [[Singapore]] for Channel HD 5 Live coverage.{{Cite episode|title=2009 Singapore Grand Prix|episodelink=2009 Singapore Grand Prix|location=Singapore|network=Channel HD 5 Live|year=2009}} "Crazy In Love" was recorded professionally and shown on [[Frecuencia Latina]] from the show in [[Lima]], [[Peru]] at the [[Estadio Monumental "U"|Explanada del Estadio Monumental]].{{Cite episode|title=Estadio Monumental "U"|episodelink=Estadio Monumental "U"|location=Lima, Peru|network=Frecuencia Latina|year=2009}} ==Opening acts== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Pussycat Dolls]] (North America) *[[RichGirl]] (North America){{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2009/06/18/richgirl-to-open-for-beyonce/ |title=RichGirl to Open for Beyoncé|work=Rap-Up|date= June 18, 2009|accessdate=June 11, 2013}} *[[Flo Rida]] (Australia){{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1620729/flo-rida-talks-big-australian-tour-with-beyonce.jhtml|title=Flo Rida Calls Touring With Beyonce In Australia 'Big For Me'|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks|first=Shaheem|last=Reid|date=April 16, 2009|accessdate=June 11, 2013}} *[[Nelly Furtado]] (Canada) *[[Eva Avila]] (Canada){{cite web|title=Beyoncé no ordinary performer|date=March 28, 2009|last=Classen|first=Stephanie|work=[[The Star Phoenix]]|publisher=[[Canwest Publishing Inc]]}} *[[Linda Teodosiu]] (Austria, Germany and Switzerland){{cite web|url=http://www.tikonline.de/music-box/pop-rock/detail.php?nr=50481&rubric=Pop&Rock|title=Linda Teodosiu: Im Vorprogramm von Beyoncé|trans-title=Linda Teodosiu the opening act for Beyonce|date=April 17, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2009|publisher=TIK Online|language=German}} *Ildiko Keresztes and Karmatronic (Hungary){{cite web|url=http://bulvar.ma.hu/tart/cikk/d/0/44219/1/bulvar/Keresztes_Ildiko_enekel_Beyonce_elott_aprilis_29en_a_Sportarenaban|title=Ildi nyitja meg a sztár káprázatos show-ját|trans-title=Ildi opens the dazzling star-show|date=April 27, 2009|accessdate=May 10, 2009|publisher=Ma.hu. The ceremony involved a dance production dedicated to Ukraine's miners. Local artists Natal'ya Mogilevskaya, Svetlana Loboda and Aliona Vinnitskaya performed Queen's "[[We Will Rock You]]". Afterwards, a speech by Victor Yushchenko, president of Ukraine was given. Knowles performed audience of nearly 45,000.{{cite web|url=http://donbass-arena.com/en/news/?id=10515|title=Beyoncé is to open Donbas Arena|date=September 8, 2009|accessdate=December 28, 2009|publisher=FC Shakhtar. PR Newswire Europe Limited |date=September 3, 2009 |accessdate=January 26, 2010}} *On June 10, 2009, Knowles was joined by [[George Michael]] on stage for the performance of "If I Were a Boy".{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/news/beyonce/124698-beyonce-george-michael|title=Beyonce Duets With George Michael|publisher=[[MTV UK]]. MTV Networks|date=June 10, 2009|accessdate=June 13, 2013}} *On June 22, 2009, Jay-Z appeared on stage with Knowles in the middle of "Crazy in Love" and rapped a verse from his song "[[I Just Wanna Love U (Give It 2 Me)]]". *On July 3, 2009, during the Essence Music Festival, Knowles dedicated the performance to Michael Jackson following his death. A video of Knowles at the age five was projected on the screen showing her doing an impression of the artist. Knowles said, "That's when I decided who I wanted to be", stating that Jackson was responsible for the inspiration. She went on to sing "Halo" dedicating the lyrics to Jackson.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1615347/beyonce-ne-yo-honor-michael-jackson-at-essence-festival.jhtml|title=Beyonce, Ne-Yo Honor Michael Jackson At Essence Festival|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks|first=Rahman|last=Dukes|date=July 6, 2009|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} *On July 16, 2009, [[Solange Knowles]] appeared as a special guest during the show which was aimed to benefit the Charles & Phyllis Newman Foundation and Knowles' charitable organization, The Survivor Foundation.{{cite press release |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/beyonce--solange-knowles-to-perform-benefit-concert-in-minneapolis-on-july-16-61881977.html|title=Beyonce & Solange Knowles to Perform Benefit Concert in Minneapolis on July 16|publisher=PR Newswire. PR Newswire Association LLC|date=June 25, 2009 |accessdate=June 11, 2013}} *On November 16, 2009, Knowles was joined on stage by [[Kanye West]] who performed "Ego", and Jay-Z who rapped his verse on "Crazy in Love".{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/kanye-west/48385|title=Kanye West and Jay-Z join Beyonce onstage at London O2 Arena|work=NME|date=November 16, 2009|accessdate=June 11, 2013}} }} == Cancelled shows == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |+ List of cancelled concerts, showing date, city, country, venue and reason for cancellation |- ! scope="col" style="width:12em;"| Date ! scope="col" style="width:10em;"| City ! scope="col" style="width:10em;"| Country ! scope="col" style="width:16em;"| Venue ! scope="col" style="width:30em;"| Reason |- |July 22, 2009 |[[Mansfield, Massachusetts|Mansfield]] |United States |[[Comcast Center (amphitheatre)|Comcast Center]] |Production and logistical issues{{cite web|url=http://news.providencejournal.com/breaking-news/2009/06/beyonce-concert.html|title=Beyoncé concert at Comcast officially canceled|accessdate=June 2, 2009|date=June 2, 2009|last=Massimo|first=Rick|work=[[The Providence Journal]]|publisher=[[A.H. revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = KamaGames | logo = KamaGames Company Logo, March 2017.png | type = Private | industry = [[Video game industry|Video games]] | hq_location = [[Dublin, Ireland]]<ref name=OfficialWebsite>{{cite web|title=KamaGames | About|url=http://kamagames.com/|website=KamaGames|publisher=KamaGames|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> | products = Social Casino Games | website = }} '''KamaGames''' is the largest European social mobile poker operator<ref>https://www.gamasutra.com/view/pressreleases/313696/Yoozoo_Games_and_KamaGames_celebrate_the_launch_of_Poker_Champions_into_the_Indian_Market.php</ref>, with over 530,000 daily active players.<ref>https://www.pocketgamer.biz/news/67880/kamagames-racks-up-100-million-players/</ref>
'''KamaGames''' has built a portfolio of free-to-play social casino titles. The company's award-winning<ref>https://egr.global/intel/news/egr-marketing-innovation-awards-2018-in-pictures/</ref>, flagship game Pokerist® Texas Poker, was the #1 grossing app in 101 countries on the App Store and in the Top 5 grossing apps in 45 countries on Google Play. <ref>https://www.idaireland.com/newsroom/kamagames-a-dublin-based-1</ref>
Other KamaGames titles include Slots, Blackjackist, Set Poker, Omaha Poker, Baccarist, Roulettist and most recently, Split Bet Poker.
KamaGames' [http://www.itechlabs.com/certificates/kamagames/RNG_Certificate_Kamagames_UK_15032018.pdf Random Number Generator] (RNG) is certified by iTech Labs and is designed to meet the highest standards to guarantee fair play. The company's products are available across mobile devices, social networking services and smart TVs.
KamaGames’ HQ is in Dublin and it employs more than 250 people worldwide. <ref>https://www.pokernews.com/news/2018/04/kamagames-updates-social-casino-portfolio-samsung-app-30561.htm</ref>
== History == KamaGames was founded in 2010. A statement from the company's website says that its mission was to create high quality, innovative and engaging social casino games for mobile and other platforms. <ref>https://www.kamagames.com/</ref> '''Pokerist''' launched that same year and remains the company's flagship title. It was followed by a range of social casino titles, including Roulettist in 2013, Baccarist in 2017 and Slots in 2018. Initially, KamaGames products were launched in Europe, but soon expanded to the US, ASIAPAC <ref>http://www.engineersjournal.ie/2015/07/14/kamagames-announces-growth-strategy-100-jobs-three-years/), </ref>, the Middle East <ref>https://www.pocketgamer.biz/news/67749/kamagames-revenues-hit-57-5-million-in-2017/</ref>, China<ref>https://www.valuebuddies.com/viewprwire.php?id=1330917</ref>, CIS countries and India. <ref>http://www.gamingintelligence.com/games/45988-kamagames-launches-poker-champions-in-india</ref> In addition to working as a developer and distributor, KamaGames has established partnerships in the US with Poker Night in America<ref>http://sbcamericas.com/2018/04/11/successful-partnerships-crucial-factor-kamagames-growth/</ref> and with Yoozoo Games with the launch of Poker Champions in India.<ref>http://www.gamingintelligence.com/games/45988-kamagames-launches-poker-champions-in-india</ref> KamaGames’ audience ranges from mobile, to social networks and to players who play the games on Smart TVs. To further expand its reach, KamaGames has partnered with social networks VK.com<ref>http://www.igamingbusiness.com/news/kamagames-launch-first-html5-title-vkcom</ref>, Facebook<ref>https://calvinayre.com/2018/02/14/press-releases/kamagames-launch-pokerist-texas-holdem-facebooks-instant-games/</ref> and with the Viber<ref>https://www.mcvuk.com/development/kamagames-bringing-games-portfolio-to-viber</ref> and the Tango messaging services. 2017 was a strong year for KamaGames with a gross revenue figure of $57.5 million being reported. According to their website, this was an increase of 63.4% on its previous year and also marked six consecutive quarters of growth for the company.<ref>https://www.kamagames.com/news/we_are_kamagames</ref> In early 2018 the company also reached the milestone of having over 100 million players<ref>http://www.igamingbusiness.com/news/kamagames-smashes-100-million-player-barrier</ref> enjoying their portfolio of social casino titles across the world.<ref>https://www.casinomeister.com/gambling-news/poker-news-weekly-round-june-1-2018/</ref>
== Product timeline == '''Pokerist Texas Poker''' KamaGames released the first version of their flagship title Pokerist Texas Poker on iOS in April 2010 followed by Android in June 2010. In April 2011 the game was released on Facebook, followed by a host of other platforms including Odnoklassniki.ru, Yandex, the Amazon Store, Windows Phone, Facebook's Instant Games, SMART TV, Samsung Galaxy Apps and Apple TV.<ref>https://calvinayre.com/2016/05/27/press-releases/kamagames-announces-new-player-research-statistics-to-mark-pokerist-texas-pokers-6th-anniversary/</ref> Pokerist is an app game based on poker. Pokerist's “Party Modes” are variations on the game, including ’10 to Ace’ (which only deals the players high-value cards), ‘Joker’ (in which Jokers are wild) and more.
'''Roulettist, Blackjackist and Baccararist''' KamaGames expanded their portfolio of social casino products with the release of Roulettist on iOS in April 2013.<ref>http://www.metacritic.com/game/ios/roulettist</ref>
Based on the classic casino game of Roulette, players are able to choose the type of game they want to play, from the classic European Roulette, to French Roulette, or riskier and American Roulette. The game was released on google play in April 2013 and then the Amazon Store on March 31st 2015.<ref>https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.kamagames.roulettist&hl=en_IE</ref>
Subsequent KamaGames titles include Blackjackist, based on Blackjack in June 2016<ref>http://www.metacritic.com/game/ios/blackjack-21-blackjackist</ref> and Baccarist, based on Baccarat in February 2017.<ref>https://www.casinopedia.org/news/kamagames-3d-baccarat-baccarist</ref>
'''Omaha and Set Poker''' KamaGames broadened their portfolio further in 2017 with the addition of Omaha Poker in April<ref>http://www.igamingbusiness.com/news/kamagames-expands-pokerist-omaha-poker</ref> and Set Poker in December<ref>https://calvinayre.com/2017/12/22/press-releases/kamagames-announces-launch-latest-game-set-poker/</ref>. The difference between Omaha and Texas Hold 'Em is that each player is dealt four cards instead of two and must make their best hand using two of them plus three of the five community cards.
'''Set Poker''' is similar to the Texas Hold ‘Em, but with side bets and with players also taking on the house. These side bets (named “Lucky 3” and “Lucky 6”) each have a set of winning combinations.
'''Slots''' Taking its inspiration from casino slot machines, Slots was added to KamaGames’ portfolio in March 2018. <ref>http://www.igamingbusiness.com/press/kamagames-announces-slots-launch</ref>
'''Craps''' Based on the immensely popular dice game enjoyed in casinos around the world, Craps is the first 3D multiplayer game of its kind launched on the '''App Store''' and '''Google Play''', released in August 2018. Players can choose from a range of betting styles, roll the dice and weigh up which odds and bets suit the most. <ref>http://g3newswire.com/ireland-kamagames-adds-craps-to-portfolio/</ref>
== Points of interest == '''Switching to the Unity engine''' In November 2016, the company announced their continued commitment to using Unity, the leading games and experience creation platform. Part of the commitment involved the conversion of its titles from iOS and Android native apps to Unity 5.<ref>https://www.pocketgamer.biz/news/64048/social-casino-developer-kamagames-moves-entire-portfolio-to-unity-5/</ref>
Unity's games engine also allows KamaGames to add a range of new features across their games portfolio including global weekly player tournaments.
'''The Manchester United Partnership''' In 2015, KamaGames was the official global social casino partner for the leading English soccer club Manchester United. Catering to the club's estimated 659 million supporters worldwide, KamaGames developed specific mobile and online social casino games featuring the club's branding, logo, imagery and themes.
Powered by KamaGames, Manchester United Social Poker and Manchester United Social Roulette, featured images of the club's first-team players and gave fans the opportunity to play and interact with other supporters from around the world. The games were released on IOS, Android, Windows, Amazon and Facebook.<ref>http://www.gamingintelligence.com/games/35590-kamagames-launches-latest-manchester-united-branded-social-app</ref>
'''Carmen Electra''' In 2012, KamaGames signed a contract with Carmen Electra to endorse its flagship title, Pokerist Texas Poker, for one year. The actress, model and singer was featured in the app, icons, banners and across a variety of promotional materials associated with the game. The contract was renewed in July 2014 until July 2016.<ref>https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20120426005594/en/Pokerist.com-Introduces-Carmen-Electra-Face-Free-To-Play-Texas</ref>
'''IOHA Sponsorship''' In March 2017, KamaGames began their sponsorship of the Irish Olympic Handball Association (IOHA) national team<ref>http://www.olympichandball.org/2017/03/23/kamagames-announced-as-national-team-sponsor/</ref>. The two-year sponsorship agreement sees KamaGames take over as the lead sponsor of the IOHA with the company's logo and branding being displayed on all men's, ladies and junior handball teams match day and training kit.
KamaGames also assists financially in the team's international games and invests in finding and training the next generation of players.
== Publishing programme == KamaGames trialed a publishing programme in June 2013 with a vision to create partnerships and support other mobile games developers. The programme offered development studios a minimum investment of US $100,000 to fund the soft launch of their game whilst also providing guidance, expertise, localisation support and other back end services. This publishing programme was phased out in 2016.<ref>https://www.adweek.com/digital/kamagames-announces-publishing-program/</ref>
'''Apple TV''' Pokerist Texas Poker was among the first games released by Apple on their Apple TV platform. The tvOS operating system, which is itself based on Apple's iOS, enables developers like KamaGames to create games specifically for Apple TVs.<ref>https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/texas-poker/id976674635?mt=8</ref>
'''HTML 5, Facebook's Instant Games and VK.com''' In early 2018, KamaGames released Pokerist Texas Holdem for Facebook's Instant Games on the HTML5 platform.<ref>http://www.igamingbusiness.com/news/kamagames-launch-first-html5-title-vkcom </ref>
These launches meant that players could access Pokerist without having to download the game and instead, access the game by tapping a button on their Facebook page or below their chats on Facebook Messenger. Games stream within the Messenger and Facebook apps, without the need to install additional apps.<ref>https://calvinayre.com/2018/02/14/press-releases/kamagames-launch-pokerist-texas-holdem-facebooks-instant-games/</ref>
Prior to the Facebook's Instant Games launch, KamaGames launched Pokerist onto VK.com’s Direct Games gaming platform in August 2017. VK.com is the largest social media network in Europe.<ref>http://www.igamingbusiness.com/news/kamagames-launch-first-html5-title-vkcom </ref>
== Publishing partners == '''KamaGames''' has collaborated with a number of publishing partners.
'''Tango Mobile''' The first of these partnerships was with Tango Mobile with the launch of Pokerist Texas Poker and Roulettist in 2014.<ref>https://www.pocketgamer.biz/news/64668/kamagames-expands-tango-partnership/</ref> In December 2016, KamaGames announced that 3D Blackjack would join Pokerist Texas Poker and Roulettist on Tango Mobile.<ref>http://www.igamingbusiness.com/news/kamagames-adds-3d-blackjack-tango </ref>
'''Viber''' In September 2016, KamaGames announced a new partnership with leading mobile messaging service platform, Viber. The deal made the innovative 3D Blackjack game available to Viber's 664 million players across 193 countries.<ref>https://www.mcvuk.com/development/kamagames-bringing-games-portfolio-to-viber</ref>
'''Spil Games''' KamaGames announced plans to release their portfolio of titles across Spil Games Portals in October 2016. The Spil Games portfolio currently reaches over 100 million active players across Europe every month.<ref>http://spil-app.pokerist.com/spil.php?gamePartner=Gry_pl&gp=1&countryCode=US&siteid=16&channelid=1&siteLocale=pl-PL&appToken=UwAB_wBhBAEA0Pu1a8gAEAEAWA7_XQgBAAAAAo8Zc2dpZF8wNDAxMDBkMGZiYjU2YmM4JhKNNRNx592maxLrxkpVaQSd629XXKsDoGVZJcpT5DstyKAyOBFkag&UID=sgid_040100d0fbb56bc8&spilStorageId=29653600413&locale=pl</ref> <ref>https://www.kamagames.com/news/kamagames-announces-partnership-with-spil-games</ref>
'''Poker Night in America''' In April 2017, KamaGames announced an ongoing partnership with [[Poker_Night_in_America|Poker Night]] in America, a TV show that broadcasts on the CBS Sports Network.<ref>https://egr.global/northamerica/news/kamagames-unveils-major-update-to-poker-night-in-america-app/ </ref>
The partnership involves the development of a standalone Poker Night in America app, developed and published under the KamaGames banner. The app is available to download from the iOS App Store and Google Play.
In March 2018, '''KamaGames''' announced a comprehensive update to coincide with the new season of Poker Night in America introducing a host of new features and additional games to the app.
'''Yoozoo games, Poker Champions and the Indian Market''' '''KamaGames''' partnered with Asian developer and publisher Yoozoo games for the release of Poker Champions into the Indian market in January 2018. Based on the globally successful social poker title Pokerist, Poker Champions adapted to give it a look and feel to appeal to the specific Indian gaming audience. As well as graphical adjustments, the in-game mechanics, specifically the Party modes, were made more fast-paced making the game a more exciting and familiar experience to Indian players.<ref>https://www.pocketgamer.biz/asia/interview/66802/kamagames-partners-with-yoozoo-india/</ref>
== Portfolio == '''Pokerist''' Pokerist Texas Hold’em is one of the world's most popular social poker games, enjoyed by over 100 million players around the globe.<ref>https://www.pokernews.com/news/2018/05/pokerist-poker-app-reaches-100-million-player-milestone-30773.htm</ref> The game has been ranked as the top grossing app in 101 countries on the App Store and one of the Top 5 grossing apps in 45 countries on Google Play.<ref>https://calvinayre.com/2018/02/14/press-releases/kamagames-launch-pokerist-texas-holdem-facebooks-instant-games/ </ref> Pokerist's features include, weekly Sit’n’Go tournaments, unique “Party modes” each with their own set of unique rules, and the hugely popular Boost Poker. Players can also collect and enjoy daily giveaways of free chips, both in-game and via Pokerist's various social network channels. Additionally, the game has evolved its communications over the years, offering players the chance to send virtual “gifts”, emojis and text messages. Pokerist is available on the world's most popular gaming platforms including the App Store, Google Play, Facebook, Amazon, Windows Apps, AppleTV, Samsung SmartTV and Samsung Galaxy Apps.
'''Roulettist''' Roulettist brings the excitement of one of the oldest casino table games to your mobile device. The game lets you choose between three different playing modes - European roulette, American roulette, or French roulette. Roulettist also has a number social features including in-game chat, animated emojis and the chance to make new friends from around the world.
'''Blackjackist''' Blackjackist takes all of the elements of the traditional game of blackjack and adds 3D motion-captured graphics. The game also takes full advantage of KamaGames’ chat system and simple, one-tap interface.
'''Baccarist''' Enjoyed by both beginners and experts, Baccarist is one of the most popular casino games in the world.<ref>https://www.casino.org/blog/figures-show-most-popular-games-on-las-vegas-strip/ </ref>
'''Slots''' Slots is a free-to-play slots game.
Play across a variety of different settings, including Genie's Cave, Cleopatra's Treasures and Buffalo Valley and watch your slots create a rich, colourful variety of winning combinations.
'''Omaha''' Differing slightly from the famous Texas Hold ‘Em, rules, Omaha deals four cards to players instead of two. Players must make their hands with two of their own cards plus a choice from the dealer’s five.
'''Set Poker''' Set Poker, also known as “3 Card Poker”, starts with a three-card deal for the player. Additionally, players are also able to place parallel bets on either side of the main deal with each one having a set of winning combinations. These side bets are appropriately named “Lucky 3” and “Lucky 6”.
== Awards and nominations == On August 8 2013, '''KamaGames''' was featured at number 14 in the SCi Power 25 Rating by Social Casino Intelligence. The SCi Power 25 Rating is compiled annually to distinguish industry leaders worldwide.
The Best Mobile App Awards recognised Pokerist Texas Poker as one of the best games of 2013 in their 2013 Overall Awards Platinum Award in the Card and Casino category.<ref>https://bestmobileappawards.com/news/2013-best-mobile-app-awards-announced</ref>
KamaGames was nominated for the Best Social Operator award for social gaming at the EGR Operator Awards for 2 years running in 2016<ref>https://egr.global/intel/news/egr_operator_awards_2016_shortlist_announced/</ref> and 2017<ref>https://egr.global/events/egr-operator-awards-2017/</ref> and won the Innovation in Social Casino at the EGR Marketing and Innovation awards in 2018.<ref>https://egr.global/intel/news/egr-marketing-innovation-awards-2018-in-pictures/</ref>
Additionally, KamaGames was named Best Mobile Games Developer 2017 at the SoftTech International awards. <ref>https://issuu.com/aiglobalmedia/docs/2017_gaming_and_entertainment_award</ref> SoftTech awards programme highlights the most innovative firms throughout the industry which offers unique and versatile services to their players.

page.title: List of shooting ranges in Akershus

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=June 2016}} {{GeoGroup}} [[File:Norway Counties Akershus Position.svg|thumb|right|[[Akershus]] on the map of [[Norway|Norge]].]] Below is a list of [[shooting range]]s in [[Akershus]] [[County municipality (Norway)|county municipality]] for [[bow and arrow|bow]], [[crossbow]], [[shotgun]], [[pistol]] and [[rifle]]. {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |- !Name !Use !Users !Municipality !Coordinates |- | Grasåsen skytesenter | Eksisterende | Bjørkelangen jeger- og fiskerforening,
Bjørkelangen pistolklubb,
Hemnes jeger- og fiskerforening,

'''Manic Pixie Dream Girl''' ('''MPDG''') is a [[stock character]] type in [[films]]. Film critic [[Nathan Rabin]], who coined the term after observing [[Kirsten Dunst]]'s character in ''[[Elizabethtown (film)|Elizabethtown]]'' (2005), said that the MPDG "exists solely in the fevered imaginations of sensitive [[Screenwriter|writer]]-[[Film director|directors]] to teach broodingly soulful young men to embrace life and its infinite mysteries and adventures."<ref name="rabin">{{cite web |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/my-year-of-flops-case-file-1-elizabethtown-the-bat,15577/ |title=My Year Of Flops, Case File 1: ''Elizabethtown'': The Bataan Death March of Whimsy |last=Rabin |first=Nathan |authorlink=Nathan Rabin |date=January 25, 2007 |website=[[The A.V. Club]] |accessdate=January 5, 2010}}</ref> MPDGs are said to help their men without pursuing their own happiness, and such characters never grow up; thus, their men never grow up.<ref name="welker">{{cite journal |last=Welker |first=Holly |date=February 12, 2010 |title=Forever Your Girl |journal=[[Bitch (magazine)|Bitch]] |issue=46 |pages=26–30 |url=https://bitchmedia.org/article/forever-your-girl |accessdate=June 26, 2016}}</ref>
The Manic Pixie Dream Girl has been compared to another stock character, the [[Magical Negro]], a [[black people|black]] character who seems to exist only to provide spiritual or mystical help to the [[White savior narrative in film|white savior protagonist]]. In both cases, the stock character has no discernible inner life, and usually only exists to provide the protagonist some important life lessons.<ref name="avclub">{{cite web |last1=Bowman |first1=Donna |last2=Gillette |first2=Amelie |last3=Hyden |first3=Steven |last4=Murray |first4=Noel |last5=Pierce |first5=Leonard |last6=Rabin |first6=Nathan |date=August 4, 2008 |title=Wild things: 16 films featuring Manic Pixie Dream Girls |website=[[The A.V. Club]] |url=http://www.avclub.com/article/wild-things-16-films-featuring-manic-pixie-dream-g-2407 |accessdate=April 16, 2009 |lastauthoramp=yes}}</ref>
==Examples== MPDGs are usually [[static characters]] who have [[Eccentricity (behavior)|eccentric]] personality quirks and are unabashedly girlish. They invariably serve as the [[romantic interest]] for a (most often brooding or depressed) male [[protagonist]]. Examples of an MPDG are described below: *An example is [[Natalie Portman]]'s character in the movie ''[[Garden State (film)|Garden State]]'' (2004), written and directed by [[Zach Braff]].<ref name="rabin"/><ref name="welker"/><ref name="salon">{{cite web |url=http://www.salon.com/mwt/broadsheet/2008/08/07/manic_pixie/ |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20111008063922/http://www.salon.com/mwt/broadsheet/2008/08/07/manic_pixie/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 8, 2011 |title=The Natalie Portman problem |last=Berman |first=Judy |date=August 7, 2008 |website=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] |accessdate=January 5, 2010 |df= }}</ref> In his review of ''Garden State'', [[Roger Ebert]] also described this kind of rather unbelievable "movie creature" as "completely available" and "absolutely desirable."<ref>{{cite web |title=Garden State |first=Roger |last=Ebert |authorlink=Roger Ebert |website=Rogerebert.com |url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/garden-state-2004 |date=August 6, 2004 |accessdate=June 26, 2016}}</ref> * ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' points to [[Katharine Hepburn]]'s character in ''[[Bringing Up Baby]]'' (1938) as one of the earliest examples of the archetype.<ref name="avclub"/> *The'' [[Filmspotting]]'' podcast created a list of Top Five Manic Pixie Dream Girls; Nathan Rabin appeared as a guest and created his own, separate list of MPDGs.<ref name="filmspotting"/>
